Professor Emeritus Percy Q. Johnstone
B00008976Y|5.0|Although &quot;Red&quot; remains my favorite installment in the Three Colors trilogy, &quot;Blue&quot; is wonderful as well. Juliette Binoche plays a grief stricken woman attempting to cope with the sudden death of her husband and daughter. She is luminous in the role, and has the remarkable ability to tell us exactly what she is thinking through her expressions rather than saying anything at all. Her desire to leave her old life behind and start anew, anonymous, in Paris, is the desire for freedom from the past (the theme of the film is liberty; for &quot;Red,&quot; it's fraternity, and for &quot;White,&quot; equality).  <br />  <br /> As she comes to terms with her grief, some of her actions may be questionable and might make the audience look unsympathetically at her character, but Binoche always seems to somehow make us understand why she is doing what she does. <br />  <br /> The manner in which the color blue is used to bring mood and atmosphere to the film is also impressive. We see Julie swimming through a pool, the scene bathed in blues; there are also blue crystals, windows, balloons, a plethora of things blue, to underscore Julie's grief. <br />  <br /> I highly recommend this film, for its superb performances and its consideration of a woman handling grief the best way she knows how.

B00003CXC7|5.0|&quot;Rear Window&quot; finds Hitchcock in top form, and is regarded as one of the director's classics. Jimmy Stewart, Grace Kelly, and Thelma Ritter are all superb in this thriller, in which L.B. Jeffries (played by Stewart) is convinced that he's witnessed a neighbor trying to cover up the murder of his wife. The set is amazing--a single courtyard surrounded by three buildings full of windows into peoples' lives, with Jeffries having full view of all this. Voyeurism becomes the most prominent theme of the movie. As Jeffries is confined to his wheelchair after breaking his leg, all he has to do all day is stare out his window and spy on his neighbors. He's a photographer by profession, though, and he's not bored for long. He enjoys watching other people, taking note of the routine and not so routine happenings. And we enjoy watching Jeffries watching everyone else. The film is not only full of suspense and well-acted, but it also has a lot to say about perspective and seeing and being seen. Highly recommended!

1582432678|4.0|This is a harrowing look at teenage violence in America. Although fictional, Shriver bases her account on the spate of killings in American high schools.           The protagonist of the novel, Eva, is happy with Franklin but on impulse she decides she wants to marry him. Their union produces Kevin, a troubling boy from the time he is born. Eva has misgivings about having a child in the first place, and whether Kevin is naturally just a nasty child or whether her reservations rub off on him and make him so is up for debate. At any rate, Kevin's behavior and attitude only get worse and, perhaps copying teenage murderers before him, tragedy at his high school ensues.          The ending is inevitably sad, but stay with it--this is a well-done, thoughtful attempt at trying to explain teenage violence in America, and one family's tragic experience with it.

(And as a side note, the version on this soundtrack is the full-length version, not the much shorter radio edit.) And although I dislike the classification as the Pumpkins as grunge, this is a great introduction and overview of the genre. Two other bands that helped shape the grunge movement, Hole and Nirvana, are absent, but I don't think that the soundtrack would be any better for their presence.      Skip the film if you wish, but this is an essential album for anyone who grew up in this time period (especially if you hail from Seattle), and a good bet for any rock fan.

038551123X|4.0|What can one say about yet again another serial killer novel. Authors are desperately trying to put a new spin on a very old and tired formula. However, Jeff Lindsay may have succeeded in making his a bit more offbeat than the vast majority. <br />     Dexter Morgan is a blood splatter analyst on the Miami PD. He is also a very disturbed man who just so happens to be a serial killer. However, his victims are serial killers themselves whether they are priests who kill children or mentally deranged janitors, Dexter finds them and kills them with great enjoyment. He now appears to be up against a killer who murders women leaving their cut up and bloodless bodies in neat little packages for the police to find. However, the killer is onto Dexter in that Dexter is finding clues in his kitchen and car indicating the killer knows who he is.  To make matters worse, Dexter is not sure if, while he supposedly dreams, he is in fact killing. Needless to say, he tries to help his sister get ahead in the police department by giving her insight into the killing- things that only another killer would know. <br />     There is a sense of originality with Dexter being a 'lovable serial killer'.  He is an original creation and a unique voice in crime fiction. The good idea, however, eventually begins to wear as thin as the uneven plot. Stereotypes abound and in spite of the uniqueness of the main protagonist, the other characters are routine creations. The conclusion is highly unrealistic and comes virtually out of nowhere. However, the length of the story is manageable and the book well edited.

B000002A3T|3.0|There is an objective fact that every Pink Floyd fan must recognize-- Roger Waters was the songwriter of the band, David Gilmour was the soul, and Wright and Mason were very talented buffers that kept the two egomaniacs from killing each other. On &quot;The Division Bell,&quot; the songwriter is gone, supplanted by a battalion of no-names who lack Waters' lyrical talents, and Gilmour has solos that, while technically impressive, are colorless and soulless.... his work on &quot;Animals&quot; and DSotM make the hairs on the back of my neck stand on end, it's so good, but here, the solos never seem to click, and some go on FOREVER. <br />  <br /> Having said that, there are some great songs on this album. When &quot;Cluster One&quot; gets going, you'd think you were back in 1971.. Gilmour employs plenty of echo effects, and Rick Wright carries on a musical conversation with him on his keyboards. The same goes for the instrumental (and Grammy-winning) &quot;Marooned.&quot; <br /> A song I really like is &quot;Wearing the Inside Out,&quot; written and sung by Rick Wright. &quot;High Hopes&quot; is a terrific song-- it is unlike any other Floyd song I've ever heard. <br />  <br /> Weak points: nearly everywhere else. Gilmour is a somewhat uninspired composer, and &quot;Take It Back&quot; and &quot;Coming Back To Life&quot; are throwbacks to &quot;A Momentary Lapse Of Reason&quot;-- something that nearly every Floyd fan wants to forget. Other songs aren't necessarily bad, just boring, such as &quot;A Great Day For Freedom,&quot; and &quot;Keep Talking.&quot; The listenter occasionally loses interest.  <br />  <br /> Overall, only about half of this album is really GOOD (but man, I LOVE &quot;High Hopes.&quot;) However, that is enough (in my book) to get it. It's great to see the boys back after the subpar &quot;Momentary Lapse,&quot; and we can only hope that there is more to come. Get it to complete your collection and enjoy a few good tracks.

The plot revolves around Police Oficer, Murphy(Peter Weller), who on his first day in a new precinct, gives persuit to a group of criminals. Overly zealous, him and his partner follow the gang into a derelict steel-works. Murphy is brutally slain by the felons, and what is left of him is turned into Robocop; a half human, half robot, law inforcement officer. Paul Verhoeven, directing his second American film, satirizes both big business, and American industrial faliure. Big business, according to Verhoeven, creats a problem(crime, drugs), then makes a product to solve it(Robocop). In one scene, OCP unveils its new ED 209 enforcement droid, to the company's board of staff. The machine malfunctions during the trial, killing a man. This peticular scene, satirizes America's industrial faliure.

B0001NBMBC|4.0|Well I guess after IOWA, they wanted to do something different and be more expiramental. They were never really havey in the first place, however this is their most mellow release to date. Dedication to craft made Slipknot kings. From the sparks of a collective genesis in the basements of Des Moines, the Iowa collective set dutifully to constructing their metallurgical music flamethrower. But there was also the crafty psy-ops deployed on a nation of malleable young minds, the agit-prop of masks, smocks, and bar codes that helped transform fans into maggots and emphasize Slipknot's larger vision of a black bag revolution over any alluring lull of individual celebrity. The Midwestern origin of all this craziness was genius, as the band's marrow-draining metal and twisted, fibrous mythology was antithetical to the region's rep. Vol. 3 does share its lyrical troika of anger, disaffection, and psychosis with most of the nu-metal pack. Lyrics like &quot;I've screamed until my veins collapsed&quot; and &quot;Push my fingers into my eyes/It's the only thing that slowly stops the ache&quot; aren't unique to the Slipknot cult, but unlike so many, the band isn't making records to appease labels. Only rarely does its music disassemble into the genre building blocks -- riff + glowering vocal + throaty chorus = Ozzfest satiety -- that clutter the efforts of their contemporaries. What makes Vol. 3 tick is the dedication made to crafting a Slipknot album, and not just another flashy Nu-Metal album. While I prefer their earlier efforts I must say that if you own the previous 3, then you must have this.

B00005A46T|5.0|When I listen to this record I hear influences of Slayer, Metallica, NIN, KoRn, and a little bit of reggae in here. This is without a shadow of a doubt Slipknot's best. The drummer is rather good, but he pales in comparison to the drummer for Cryptopsy. After a couple years of relentless touring in support of their self-titled breakthrough album, Slipknot regrouped to record Iowa, an ode to their home state and one that consolidates and punctuates everything that had garnered the band its cultish following known as &quot;the maggots.&quot; The guitar crunch, the concrete-dense rhythmic foundation, the frenzied singing, and the overall madcap fashion of it all Slipknot's trademark sound is very much at the forefront of this dark, dark album and is presented in epic form on the extended, album-closing title track, which brings to mind Children of the Corn-type terrors. Though not quite as commercially viable as the more straightforward Slipknot album, Iowa is a more interesting album. It also has a more Industrial Metal influence and feel to it, but still remains true to the Nu-Metal genre. However for those of you who are brave enough to venture further into metal I recommend better and far heavier bands like Suffocation, Nile, Decapitated, Origin, Cryptopsy, Immolation, Vital Remains, Dying Fetus, Meshuggah, Strapping Young Lad, and Gorguts.

B00000JCOV|5.0|I like this band and there isn't anything they can do to change my mind. You know what, I know what deathmetal and thrash metal is, and I also know that Slipknot is neither of those. Slipknot is Nu-Metal, and as a fan of all types of metal, I can say that this is the best band that Nu-Metal has to offer. Slipknot's mix of grinding, post-Korn alternative metal, Marilyn Manson-esque neo-shock rock, and rapcore helped make them one of the most popular bands in the so-called nu-metal explosion of the late '90s. These guys are something else entirely. And it's pretty impressive. Although those lyrics that are discernible are not generally quotable on a family website, suffice it to say that the members of Slipknot are not impressed with their fathers, their hometown, or most anything else. &quot;Surfacing&quot; starts out by cursing pretty much everything generally, and then it starts getting aggressive, as shrieking guitar feedback alternates with DJ scratching. &quot;Spit It Out&quot; is speed Nu-metal with an actual melody in the chorus; &quot;Scissors&quot; ends the program with a sound that quite simply couldn't get any more aggro without falling apart entirely and by the end, the singer actually sounds like he's about to burst into tears. Now alot of &quot;metalheads&quot; are dissing these guys and their fans for liking them. Why? Because they get mad hearing the &quot;maggots&quot; going around and saying these guys are the heaviest ever, which isn't true at all. Slipknot is pretty tame compared to Meshuggah, Slayer, Dying Fetus, Immolation, Cryptopsy, Suffocation, Nile, Origin, Strapping Young Lad, Decapitated, etc...the list goes on. Yeah thank you &quot;metalheads&quot; for telling us what to do, telling us what we can and can't listen to, and thank you for conforming to every other &quot;metalheads&quot; beliefs. Many &quot;metalheads&quot; won't give this band a chance because they don't want to be labeled as posers. Well you know what, I know what I like, and I like Slipknot. There's nothing you can say or do that will change that. This is not as good as IOWA, but it is better than Mate, Feed, Kill, Repeat and Subliminal Verses Vol. 3. Buy this today, and also check out the bands mentioned above if you want REALLY extreme and heavy music.

I was brought to tears by the woman who discovered her husband might be cheating on her (...). I wish that storyline had been better developed.       There are a lot of cheesy parts to the movie, yes, but I think it was supposed to be cheesy, not serious. So, overall I would recommend it. I think it's a good movie in the \\"cheese\\" genre.
B000021YQV|5.0|My previous reviews were deleted I guess because of arguing with that ignorant so and so KarlMarx, so I better re-do my review more politely. <br />  <br /> Let me tell you about System of a Down ladies & gentlemen, SOAD is the most creative, original, exciting band in music right now. Daron Malakian is an incredible song writer, he is the talent of this band, this guy seems to have a talent of thinking up radical ideas for songs in his head but then actually getting them to work and putting them on record. For example lets take the song &quot;Chop Suey&quot;, this is a perfect example to sum up SOAD in 3 minutes, because this song takes you on a complete rollercoaster of a ride (in just 3.30 mins), its an amazing whirlwind of time changes, differing emotions & radical musical textures. This is the kind of song most of us will struggle to think up in our heads, no matter how imaginative you may be, but to mould a song out of what you think up in your head is the hard part, but Malakian does it. <br />  <br /> &quot;Chop Suey&quot; is a relatively short song, but its also an EPIC, it has the swift brutality of a punk rock classic yet it also has the complexity & variation of a 9 minute prog rock track. Genius. From the opening spine tingling acoustic strum, to the chaotic, agressive midpoint, to the intense emotional balladry of the outro, this is 3 and a half minutes of pure genius. Just take a look at the writing credits on this album and you will see who runs the show in this band...its Daron Malakian. <br />  <br /> He's not the only talent in the band however, Serj Tankian is an amazing vocalist, best displayed on &quot;Aerials&quot; here he shows his awesome vocal range. Complete with John Dolymayan's incredibly powerful drumming & Rick Rubin's, as always, stellar production work you have the best rock album in years. <br />  <br /> And to all those who say System are sell outs & that they are mainstream rubbish let me tell you how it is, the reason SOAD sell alot of records and this album debuted at #1 on the US album charts (on the morning of 9/11) is because whatever you may think about the state of the music industry, there is still a market for real music, there is a huge fan base for cutting edge music like this, this is why SOAD sell a lot, not because they are mainstream or MTV driven, but because people are sick of that kind of stuff and want real music, here is where SOAD step in, so don't call them mainstream garbage because their music isn't mainstream, their music is intelligent, challenging and as raw as you can get, how many millions it sells is irrelevant. <br />  <br /> Now for my ratings: <br />  <br /> Prison Song: 9/10 <br /> Needles: 9.5/10 <br /> Deer Dance 9.5/10 <br /> Jet Pilot 7/10 <br /> X 9/10 <br /> Chop Suey 10/10 <br /> Bounce 6/10 <br /> Forest 9/10 <br /> ATWA 10/10 <br /> Shimmy 8/10 <br /> Science 10/10 <br /> Toxicity 9/10 <br /> Psycho 8/10 <br /> Aerials 11/10 *** best track <br />
B000002B7Y|5.0|No Rest For The Wicked(1988). Ozzy Osbourne's Fifth Album, and the First to Feature Guitarist Zakk Wylde.<br /><br /> After Guitarist Jake Lee's departure from Ozzy's band after recording 'Bark At The Moon' and 'The Ultimate Sin', Ozzy was on the search for a new guitarist, and he would soon be blessed with one of the finest. After being impressed by tapes of Guitar Instructor Zakk Wylde, Ozzy immediately recruited Wylde to his band. Immediately Wylde hit off with Ozzy, taking Ozzy's sound more away from the Neo-Classical Guitar of Randy Rhoads and the Bluesy Metal sound of Jake Lee to a Thrash Metal guitar style courtesy Zakk Wylde, emploring the techniques of fellow rockers like Metallica, yet adding a sludgy/squealy sound of his own, not to mention absolutely amazing solos. In the coming years, his style was used by Jerry Cantrell(Alice In Chains), but his influential style and guitar mastery set him apart from other guitarists. Upon its release in 1988, 'No Rest For The Wicked' climbed to the Billboard Top 20, and spawned the MTV Video Hits 'Miracle Man', 'Breaking All The Rules', and 'Crazy Babies', proving Ozzy was as successful as ever, and only would get more popular with 1991's 'No More Tears'. So, is 'No Rest For The Wicked' an underrated and overlooked part of Ozzy's career, or is it simply Ozzy trying to find his sound? Read On To Find Out....<br /><br /> Track Ratings-<br /><br /> Miracle Man- 'Miracle Man' starts the album off loud and hard, an insulting ode to TV Evangelist Jimmy Swaggert, who constantly claimed Ozzy was a Satan Worshipper. Wylde's chugging riffs and odd feedback noises, combined with a Eddie Van Halen inspired guitar solo shows Wylde can rip on the guitar with the best of them. Ozzy's sarcastic vocals definitely help 'Miracle Man' to be a Top-Notch Heavy Rocker.<br /><br /> Devil's Daughter(Holy War)- 'Devil's Daughter' blares out with Wylde's squealing riff, but soon Ozzy takes center-stage with his questioning vocals that flow easily into the more up-beat chorus. 'Devil's Daughter' particuarly stands out for the odd musical interlude with a squealing baby, but soon Wylde comes back and rips one of the longest and best solos of his career. Great song!<br /><br /> Crazy Babies- 'Crazy Babies' is perhaps Ozzy's oddest song, and his high-pitched opening vocals are priceless. Ozzy's oddly challenging vocals(listen to the chorus!)take center-stage, but Wylde's Ambulance Guitar Effect and solo back Ozzy up perfectly, making 'Crazy Babies' a fun odd Heavy Metal Rocker!<br /><br /> Breaking All The Rules- 'Breaking All The Rules' arguably accomplishes the fact that Ozzy does in fact not care about rules, with his sarcastic vocals, lyrics, chorus, and Wylde's pulsing guitar riff.Ozzy's ode to Anarchy,'Breaking All The Rules' is a great Sarcastic Hard Rocker.<br /><br /> Bloodbath In Paradise- 'Bloodbath In Paradise' is Ozzy's criticism of the Vietnam War, yet it gives you the feeling as if you just stepped into a Horror Movie, with Ozzy's gory lyrics and spooky vocals combined with the sinister guitar riff making 'Bloodbath In Paradise' my favorite track off 'No Rest For The Wicked'. The band Anthrax was an influence for Ozzy probably for this song.<br /><br /> Fire In The Sky- 'Fire In The Sky' is a heartbroken ballad, and no Ozzy album is complete without one. Ozzy's utterly tear-jerking vocals behind Wylde's steadily piercing Electric Guitar proves Ozzy can dish out ballads like no other.<br /><br /> Tattooed Dancer- 'Tatooed Dancer' is perhaps 'No Rest For The Wicked''s weakest track, because Wylde's guitar riff and Ozzy's vocals sound much like the other tracks, not really setting this one apart. Still, 'Tatooed Dancer' is an awesome track, sporting some creepy musical interludes and a short but sweet solo courtesy Wylde.<br /><br /> Demon Alchohol- 'Demon Alchohol' starts off very doomy, featuring a spooky guitar riff behind Ozzy's creepy vocals(Much like 'No More Tear''s &quot;Mr. Tinkertrain&quot;), but soon 'Demon Alchohol' switches gears to be a Light Hard Rocker with a particular Van Halen influenced sound. 'Demon Alchohol' is an excellent Fast Paced Rocker.<br /><br /> Extra Tracks:<br /><br /> Hero- 'Hero' starts off loudly with Wylde's squealing high-pitched riff, but soon 'Hero' slows down, incorporating Ozzy's symphonic vocals, Wylde's slowly chugging guitar riff, and a touch of a synth bassline to make 'Hero' a Hard Rocking Ballad that won't fail to please. Don't Skip It! One of NRFtW's Best!<br /><br /> The Liar- 'The Liar' is a Keyboard and Synthesizer Heavy Ballad, and very much sounds like his material on 'Ozzmosis' or 'Down To Earth'. Ozzy's vocals are a tad whiny and the guitar work is non-existent(other than the beautiful solo) but 'The Liar' still is a great listen.<br /><br /> Miracle Man(LIVE)- 'Miracle Man' played live sounds just as good as its studio counterpart, and Ozzy's stage prescense and energetic crowd involvement make it maybe more interesting than the original.<br /><br /> Overall, 'No Rest For The Wicked' proved that Ozzy once again dominated the Heavy Metal scene, but more importantly, it showed the world Zakk Wylde, whose work on 'No More Tears', 'Ozzmosis', 'Down To Earth' and with his band Black Label Society never would have happened without his phenomenal debut 'No Rest For The Wicked', an album that rightfully sits alongside more popular Ozzy albums such as 'Blizzard of Ozz' or 'No More Tears'.<br /><br /> HIGHLY RECOMMENDED! IF YOU ARE A FAN OF OZZY, HEAVY METAL, METAL, HARD ROCK, 80'S ROCK, ZAKK WYLDE, ALICE IN CHAINS, OR YOU DISLIKE JIMMY SWAGGERT, I CAN'T RECOMMEND 'NO REST FOR THE WICKED' MORE! IT'S NOT OZZY'S BEST, BUT ONE OF THE BEST!<br /><br /> Also Recommended-<br /><br /> Diary of a Madman- Ozzy Osbourne<br /><br /> No More Tears- Ozzy Osbourne<br /><br /> 1919 Eternal- Black Label Society<br /><br /> Thanks For Reading!ear''s &quot;Mr. Tinkertrain&quot;), but soon 'Demon Alchohol' switches gears to be a Light Hard Rocker with a particular Van Halen influenced sound. 'Demon Alchohol' is an excellent Fast Paced Rocker. <br />  <br /> Extra Tracks: <br />  <br /> Hero- 'Hero' starts off loudly with Wylde's squealing high-pitched riff, but soon 'Hero' slows down, incorporating Ozzy's symphonic vocals, Wylde's slowly chugging guitar riff, and a touch of a synth bassline to make 'Hero' a Hard Rocking Ballad that won't fail to please. Don't Skip It! One of NRFtW's Best! <br />  <br /> The Liar- 'The Liar' is a Keyboard and Synthesizer Heavy Ballad, and very much sounds like his material on 'Ozzmosis' or 'Down To Earth'. Ozzy's vocals are a tad whiny and the guitar work is non-existent(other than the beautiful solo) but 'The Liar' still is a great listen. <br />  <br /> Miracle Man(LIVE)- 'Miracle Man' played live sounds just as good as its studio counterpart, and Ozzy's stage prescense and energetic crowd involvement make it maybe more interesting than the original. <br />  <br /> Overall, 'No Rest For The Wicked' proved that Ozzy once again dominated the Heavy Metal scene, but more importantly, it showed the world Zakk Wylde, whose work on 'No More Tears', 'Ozzmosis', 'Down To Earth' and with his band Black Label Society never would have happened without his phenomenal debut 'No Rest For The Wicked', an album that rightfully sits alongside more popular Ozzy albums such as 'Blizzard of Ozz' or 'No More Tears'.  <br />  <br /> HIGHLY RECOMMENDED! IF YOU ARE A FAN OF OZZY, HEAVY METAL, METAL, HARD ROCK, 80'S ROCK, ZAKK WYLDE, ALICE IN CHAINS, OR YOU DISLIKE JIMMY SWAGGERT, I CAN'T RECOMMEND 'NO REST FOR THE WICKED' MORE! IT'S NOT OZZY'S BEST, BUT ONE OF THE BEST! <br />  <br /> Also Recommended- <br />  <br /> Diary of a Madman- Ozzy Osbourne <br /> No More Tears- Ozzy Osbourne <br /> 1919 Eternal- Black Label Society <br />  <br /> Thanks For Reading! <br />  <br />  <br />  <br />  <br />  <br />  <br />  <br />

B00005JN2F|5.0|Remembered enjoying the last movie, it inspired me to start reading the series (sure the movies don't follow the books, but c'mon, different media, not fair to compare...) and see this movie.  I read reviews on Rotton Tomatoes and was expecting camera work on level of Blair Witch.  There isn't any or I didn't notice it.  Things start moving from jump and don't stop until the end when the credits start rolling.  And in that sense, the camera seems to keep pace with the action.  There's no roller coaster pans or slo-mo bullet cams though!  I enjoy these films for their execution.  It's a rarity when an action/adventure film isn't driven by a hail of bullets, gore, and tacky, catchprhase, jingoistic dialogue.  Those movies are insulting to watch.  And while the plot/story is simple and simplified, Damon's face and delivery are on the mark, I didn't notice music (I hate melodramatic action music) and the scenes and locations seem genuine.  It's more action than intrigue, but see this movie even if you didn't see the last (it's self-contained) or even if you read the books (don't be a snob).
B000006Y12|5.0|Every so often we are presented with listening opportunities that change our lives, baffle our hearing, and grant us the pleasure to be in the company of such greatness. The Gallery is no exception and hands down the greatest melo-death release in history, setting the standard for this genre, which still hasn't been surpassed or even rivaled, and probably will never be, for its sheer timelessness, even by greats such as Jester Race era In Flames, Burning Bridges Arch Enemy, and Predator's Portrait Soilwork. There is just no comparison to an album displaying musical genius in songwriting, melody, and lyrical content without one weak moment. Now onto the details: <br /> The dual guitar harmonozing is among the best out there, not only in this style, but in all forms of metal as well. The lead passages alternate with the time changes in perfect intricacy. The drum patterns hold the backbone of this legend together like no other, and the bass is actually heard, unlike many metal bands out there today, and surely stands out as a solo instrument in the intro to &quot;Lethe&quot; (Yes that's a 5-string bass they're using). <br /> The vocals should receive no complains from even the uninitiated into the death/black metal growls. They match the mood of the music perfectly and, guess what, you actually understand what is being sung. And the lyrical content is some of the greatest work I've ever read about the themes of love and death, on par with the likes of Opeth. <br /> If you call yourself a devoted metal fan, go out and purchase the godliness that is Dark Tranquillity now without regret! If you have been wise enough to already do so, I commend you for your great taste in music. And after that, pick up Damage Done, further pick up all the albums by these guys, you won't be disappointed. You will forget that such a thing as MTV's mainstream rock exists after hearing this masterpeace. The gods of Olympus overlook this grand creation and Dionysus smiles and applauds as he has never done before!

First she hires onto his staff and embarasses herself profusely, then there are a few not-particularly-romantic scenes of them going about their general business. When the PM finds her in an awkward situation with the President of the United States, he quietly has her transferred to another department, thinking that's the end of it.  <br />  <br /> Upon the unexpected receipt of a Christmas card from her, the PM suddenly realizes he loves her, which makes no sense since as far as we the audience know, he doesn't really even know her that well. It wasn't very believable to me that a man in his position would go to so much trouble to pursue a woman unless he suspected that she was pretty special, and I didn't get the sense from the story that he could have known enough about her to justify the lengths he went to. <br />  <br /> All in all, \\"Love Actually\\" is a fun movie with a positive message about weathering the good and bad of romantic relationships (and platonic ones like the aging rock star and his manager), so long as you're willing to overlook a few unbelievable aspects of the storyline.

B00003CXXM|4.0|The Bourne Identity is a well made thriller about a covert agent who's 'malfunctioned' and wakes with amnesia. Matt Damon, who plays Jason Bourne, aka several other names, finds himself unable to remember who he is and at the same time aware that he's got a few 'skills' that seperate him from the rest of normal society.<br /><br />Set on location in Switzerland and France, this well-paced story moves right along. Along with Damon there is Franka Potente who he meets as he attempts to speak with someone at the U.S. embassy in Zurich. Offering her money to drive him to Paris in search of his identity, she accepts with reservations. And so the chase begins. Other agents like Bourne are called into action to find him and a series of chases and assasination attempts ensues.<br /><br />The characters playing these Bourne-like agents aren't really delved into, which is a shame. This also calls to mind the major weakness in the story- the U.S. government controllers who are after him. The role of 'controller' is stereotypically played throughout and it's perhaps the only weakness in the movie.<br /><br />The Bourne Identity isn't great movie-making; what it is is good entertainment. A good cast, script and well paced action scenes move the plot along at a steady pace. I thoroughly enjoyed it and hope to see its sequel very soon.

B0001HAHXW|4.0|Eric's love of Johnson's music is probably over chronicled. Why did it take so long for this tribute? His answer is that he's finally not afraid to do the project, that he has enough distance from Eric's youthful adulation and awe to meet the project with confidence. This collection is not a faithful purist recreation of Robert Johnson, but an amalgam of musical styles that a mature Clapton brings to each song. It is reminiscent of Peter Green with Nigel Watson & Splinter Group. Green et. al and Clapton approach Johnson's material with maturity, understatement, and a good reason to continue listening to their CDs all the way through, instead of shaking your head in disgust while quickly reaching for Robert's original versions. If Clapton wasn't famous, this CD would generate a buzz anyway. It's worth buying if you are a Clapton fan who shied away from his pop drivel, and worth buying if you are a blues fan. Also, try Green's &quot;Hot Foot Powder&quot; a Robert Johnson tribute that preceeded Clapton's by a couple of years.
B00005JMEW|3.0|To say this is a Quentin Tarantino action movie pretty much tells the whole story (if you know Quentin Terantino's other films). However, as I'm a much more long-winded guy than that, I'll supply some details. It has been amply publicized that Kill Bill is an homage (or blatent copy) of Kung Fu/Samurai films (mainly the latter because everyone has a sword), but updated in the same way that Raiders of the Lost Ark updated B-movie serials of the '40's (this is Tarantino's analogy). The story: An assasin tries to retire and goes into hiding, but is found and murdered on her wedding day, along with her entire wedding party and unborn child. But wait! Despite being shot in the head and spending 4-years in a coma, a scant few months after awakening she is the greatest sword-fighter in the world. If this sounds rediculous, it's because logic and plot should not really be contemplated when discussing this film. <br />  <br /> Uma Thurman plays the not-quite-killed Bride who seeks revenge on her former colleagues, who include Lucy Liu, Vivica Fox, and Daryl Hannah. These 4 women in a film together makes it worth viewing, and they all reach a kind of sublime corniness - the entire film is a wink at the audience, but the actors never let themselves in on the joke. The action and the swordplay are a delight to watch. It is extremely violent, but in a corny, stylised way (much like the Evil Dead films) - limbs are severed and fountains of blood spray out. That no one bleeds to death after losing this much blood is part of the joke. <br />  <br /> There are great highlights to the film. I especially liked The Bride's excape from the hospital after awakening from her coma, and the opening battle of the film with the Fox character. Unfortunately, the culminating battle - with Liu's private army of 88 sword-weilding grunts plus her personal assistants - goes on far too long and frankly gets boring. The most disappointing aspect of the film, however, is the startling lack of dialogue. I go to see Tarantino films for the intercharacter banter - see Pulp Fiction, for example. Here, the plot is so action-driven the characters have little chance to speak, and when they do, it's banal speeches like the one Liu delivers after decapitating a lieutenant for having the gall to disparage her Chinese heritage. <br />  <br /> These disappointments are somewhat petty - the film is not supposed to be about dialogue, after all. However, this DVD edition is a big disappointment. It looks and sounds great, but that is expected of a 2003 release. No, it's the lack of extras that robs a star from my rating of the film - Tarantino is such an interesting guy, very self-aware and knowledgeable, so why isn't there a director's commentary? No, all we get on this DVD is a short making-of featurette that looks like it was assembled from bits that appeared on Entertainment Tonight. I refuse to purchase Mirimax DVD's because they are so bare-bones it's not worth the money. I will wait and hope for a &quot;special edition&quot; box set packaging Vol. 1 and 2 together.
0812550706|4.0|I recently finished Ender's Game and enjoyed it more than most books of the Sci-Fi or Fantasy genre I have read. Orson Scott Card is a gifted writer. His charcterizations are wonderful and the story is engaging. <br /> <br />This book was recommended to me by a guy I recently met. I had not met many others that had read another series that has turned into my favorite epic saga of all time...that being George R. R. Martin's 'A Song of Ice and Fire.' Seeing that he was in agreement with me on Martin's series, I thought I'd give Ender's Game a try.  <br /> <br />I had really high expectations for it and this is something I try not to do, because most of the time they can never be reached, no matter how good a book. And, unfortunately, I think it happened here too.  <br /> <br />The book kept me interested throughout and proved to be quite interesting. The climax was not as big an event for me as I was hoping, possibly because I had an inkling of what would happen, and it did. I'd say more but I don't want to give anything away. <br /> <br />I definitely recommend this book regardless. It is enjoyable and is a good read that is not too long. I'd recommend ignoring all those reviews that gave this book (or any book for that matter) 1 or 5 stars. The 1 star reviews are all worthless. A 1 star review on a book like this is typically someone that has a negative outlook on anything popular. The 5 star reviews are more likely to be genuine though maybe over the top on the praise. That's just my general take on most reviews.  <br /> <br />Anyway, get the book and read it, you won't be disappointed and you'll be satisfied with the time spent. <br /> <br />Enjoy!

B00008EY65|3.0|If you liked Raiders of the Lost Ark, MIB, Star Wars, and any super hero movie over the last twenty years or so, you should like Hellboy.  One reason may be that Hellboy lifts, pretty blatantly, from a number of those films.  You will find yourself often recalling scenes from other films.  And that's ok, Spielburg has made quite a career from such a practice, though his lift jobs are usually from older, somewhat forgotten greats.  Hellboy just says to heck with this memory thing, and lets rip. To some extent this makes for a crowded movie.  In contrast, look how Spiderman makes much of just one super villain per movie.<br /><br />Perlman is excellent as Hellboy. He plays the part like some orange, mutant looking, cigar chomping, Sgt. Fury.  Also of note, is Liz (played by the lovely Selma Blair) as the Firestarter.  She's just one of those actresses that has \\"It,\\" just by being on screen (see: Scarlet Johansson).  The story is basically a comic book, the violence, bloodless.  You got those reliable bad guys, the Nazis (with some help from Rasputin) seeking to open up another world and let the tentacled baddies come rolling in (very Cthulu Mythos by the way).  Hellboy slugs and wisecracks his way through the evil mumbo jumbo, while keeping a protective eye out for his beloved Liz, who can take care of herself in a very explosive way.  That's pretty much it.  Nothing great, but definitely worth a watch.

B000005JA8|5.0|I bought Trout Mask Replica from a bargain bin at Rhino Records (way before it was a label) in Westwood in 1971. The _only_ reason I bought it was that I saw Frank Zappa's name on it as producer. I listened to Record 1 Side 1, I said, ``Whaa?'' and put the album in the back row of my collection for one year. (I did the exact same thing for Pierre Boulez' le marteau sans maitre, by the way.) When I listened for the second time, I listened to the music and didn't let the wierdness get the better of me. I have since ground down the grooves of three vinyl albums, until I got the current CD. It's a matter of understanding it, of &quot;getting it&quot; - I don't mean &quot;getting it&quot; like a joke, but becoming aware of the logic and compositional technique underlying the chaos. Many Beefheart fans said ``Whaa?'' at first. If you do, just put it away for a while, don't toss it in the garbage. Once you get it, you'll be amazed over and over and over again. Harmonies, rhythms and poly-rhythms, textures and lyrics the like of which the world has never heard before, or since. This is chamber music for rock band. It is delicious.

B0001XAPX8|5.0|This movie is at least as much about the past as it is about the present; the past receives virtually equal screen time through flashbacks. Certain reviewers have complained that it is 'pompous', I suppose because it takes place in a college environment, or that both Anthony Hopkins and Nicole Kidman are miscast. It concerns a classics professor, age 71, African American though nearly white in appearance, who is falsely accused of racism and quits in protest; this event kills his wife; he soon becomes involved with a distinctly intellectually inferior woman whom, through sex and other forms of communication, he soon comes to consider his soul mate, despite opposition both from his lawyer and from her boorish former husband. It is in fact a good match, between an intelligent man who is somewhat over the hill physically and a vital young woman whose former husband and 2 dead children would make anyone cry. Ed Harris is superbly evil as her insanely jealous ex-husband who knows she is having sex with another man. Faunia is a somewhat pitiable character, not too bright, who works as a cleaning woman. There is also a writer who is hired to write Coleman's biography. Faunia's chain smoking, which is sometimes gratuitous in Hollywood movies, in this case is effective in defining her character.      At least half the movie concerns Coleman's young manhood, during which time he rejected his African American family and set out to live life as white, and Jewish. These flashbacks show him as a successful undefeated boxer in his youth and also reveal an affair he had with a college student of Scandinavian descent.     In the present he still considers himself white and cannot bring himself to reveal his past, although it might have saved his job. The lovers die in a car accident, which provides the forum for more reminiscences on Coleman's life. I thought this was a fine film and deserved a strong 4 stars.

0448060191|5.0|If recommending a classic novel to someone who wants to read examples of good writing, no recommendation would be complete without the addition of Little Women, and the four March sisters; Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy.  It is a story about the devotion of these four young sisters to each other, to their family, and to their friends. No matter what the age, all of us must learn to endure the obstacles that life will throw us.  So it is in this story. Although originally written in 1898, this novel transcends time.  Alcott weaves the story of these sisters as they search for love, security, peace, and happiness. \\"Christmas won't be Christmas without any presents,\\" grumbled Jo, lying on the rug.  So begins this richly written story. Even if you have seen the movie, do try reading this beautiful classic.  Perhaps we can learn a thing or two from a classic writer. <br /> <br />It transcends all time.  It doesn't matter if the time frame is the late 1800's; good writing is good writing, which should lead to good reading.  Louisa May Alcott was so ahead of her time in writing about spirited, independent women in a time when it was not fashionable to be so.  If you liked this book, you may want to refer to other books by Alcott, but I still believe this is by far her best. <br /> <br />

1400032717|5.0|By turns heartwarming and heartbreaking, Haddon's book explores new territory -- that of an autistic fifteen-year-old boy seeking to make sense of an emotionally complex world.  Literal and logical, mathematically-gifted, Christopher sees each day as a puzzle to be solved, just as he sees the curious death of a neighbor's dog as a mystery worthy of his detective work.  His notes become this book.    Often the world is too dense with detail.  He recoils from overload and withdraws to protect himself: by hiding, groaning to block out stimuli, rocking, losing himself in mathematical puzzles, and even hitting others to forestall their unwanted advances.  He avoids crowds, being touched, the colors yellow and brown, metaphors and jokes.  So long as he can render a day by a concrete timetable, he can navigate relatively unthreatened.    Sadly, his world is altered in ways beyond his grasp when he discovers what really happened to the dog, as welll as his father and mother.  He seeks protection in the only way he knows, and somehow finds his way to a train that takes him to London, evading police and other well-intentioned folks along the way.  In the end, he has arrived as close to home and understanding as he can get.    Haddon has written a remarkable book.  That he can tell this tale from the point of view of Christopher is a staggering achievement.  That he can maintain an emotionally detached voice while generating such emotion for the reader is incredible.    I recommend this book highly, and I recommend it in relation to another remarkably touching work, THE DOGS OF BABEL.

B0000073I5|5.0|Before he formed his side project Mike + The Mechanics in 1985, Genesis bassist/guitarist Mike Rutherford recorded a pair of solo albums, and 1979's &quot;Smallcreep's Day&quot; was the first. Being Rutherford's solo debut, it was only natural that the album would sound a lot like Genesis in parts, but hey, there's nothing wrong with that! Mike recruited his old Genesis friend Anthony Phillips (the band's original guitarist) to play keyboards on the album, along with drummer Simon Phillips (no relation) and lead singer Noel McCalla. The end result is a brilliant album, with terrific compositions, performances, and production all the way around. Personal faves include the powerful rock of &quot;Moonshine&quot; and &quot;Overnight Job,&quot; the beautiful &quot;Every Road&quot; and &quot;Time And Time Again,&quot; and of course, the epic title rock suite, comprising tracks one to seven on the CD, including the thunderous &quot;Working In Line,&quot; the bouncy &quot;Cats And Rats (In This Neighborhood),&quot; and the lovely finale, &quot;At The End Of The Day,&quot; showing that Mike hasn't forgotten his &quot;Supper's Ready&quot; days in Genesis. Although it would take him until the formation of Mike + The Mechanics to *truly* step out of Genesis' shadow, &quot;Smallcreep's Day&quot; is an outstanding first solo step for Mike Rutherford.   (NOTE: the CD version of &quot;Smallcreep's Day&quot; flips around the two halves of the album, *beginning* with the &quot;Smallcreep's Day&quot; suite, which was actually Side Two of the original vinyl release. So, if you'd like to hear the album as Mike originally intended, begin the CD with track 8 (&quot;Moonshine&quot;), and when the disc ends, start the CD at the top to hear the second half. Maybe you won't care, but that's how *I* like to play &quot;Smallcreep's Day&quot; on my CD player.)

B00005JMJ4|3.0|Bill Murray displays some good comedic range in this comedy, but it is certainly not in the vein of a goofball Bill Murray comedy like Caddyshack or Kingpin. Instead, writer/director Sofia Coppola's humor is frequently so deadpan and understated, that if you're not paying strict attention (which I wasn't after the first hour), you will miss some of the film's funnier moments.        Murray's character is a tragicomic character, isolated in a foreign land without family or friends and both loving and hating it. Scarlett Johannsen's character brings some interest to the film, although her character's relationship with her on-screen husband (Giovanni Rubisi) is sadly underdeveloped, and the film ends on a note of ambivalence, not unlike my feelings towards the film.        While there is obviously some cross-cultural and situational humor, most is worthy of only a momentary chuckle. In fact, the entire theme of the film seems moodily subdued, as if the entire cast and crew of the film secretly had its water drugged with a depressant. The film itself is comedy on valium, and while it was a diverting and entertaining viewing experience with a few subtle messages on relationships and fame, I cannot understand the Oscar nominations. Above average film? Yes. Worthy of an academy award. (Yawn) No.
B00006879E|3.0|Maroon 5's Songs About Jane was released in June 2002 and it took a long climb into the top ten peaking at number seven earlier this year. The album is a mix of bluesy, white soul music with a dash of funk throw in. The band has a strong and slick musicianship and lead singer Adam Levine has a pretty decent voice. Mr. Levine is a romantic at heart and his lyrics are ripe with obsessions about beauty and lust. The first single from the album &quot;Harder To Breathe&quot; shows the band's soulful side while &quot;Shiver&quot; is in the funk-blues vein. &quot;Must Get Out&quot; is a slow, pretty song. The album's best track and a truly great single is &quot;This Love&quot;. The song has a pumping, sing-along chorus, funky guitar riff and pounding piano that create a real, old-fashion soul rave-up. The rest of the album is solid, but not spectacular.

B0000931OG|3.0|When Think Tank first came out, I was greatly turned off by the morbid cover art and explicit content patch. I thought one of my favorite groups had turned into some sort of crappy death metal band. Thankfully they didn't go that far, but I do think that Think Tank is a prime example of a great band struggling to create something magnificent and groundbreaking out of nothing. Up until Think Tank, I knew I could always listen to a Blur album and hear wry, intelligent lyrics, catchy riffs and many polished, infectious melodies. Now though, Blur comes off as a sullen, anti-establishment Radiohead impostor. Songs like Country House, On Your Own, Boys and Girls, You're So Great and Coffee and TV are songs that I think show what Blur is all about. Nothing from this new album stays with me like these older tracks. Everything from the dull opener Ambulance to the maudlin closer Battery In Your Leg is more or less watered down and lacking in the kind of vigorous musicianship that usually abounds in most Blur recordings. A few exceptions that I think are very cool tunes include the haunting Caravan, the long, rambling experimentation of Jets and the surprisingly sweet Sweet Song. I'll give Think Tank three stars for three good songs, but other than that, stick to Parklife or The Great Escape.

B00028HBKM|5.0|No movie in years has inspired half as much controversy as Mel Gibson's labor of love, the intimately religious movie &quot;The Passion of the Christ.&quot; A gritty, dark, bloody retelling of Christ's final hours, this takes the old cleaned-up Bible stories and throws them out. Instead, we have a vivid, shocking picture that you won't be able to forget.<br /><br /> This is, in essence, a cinematic passion play: We are shown Jesus's (Jim Caviezel) temptation by a surprisingly eerie Satan (Rosalinda Celentano), and his arrest by the Romans. His apostles flee away, leaving his mother Mary (Maia Morgenstern), follower Mary Magdalene (Monica Bellucci) to follow him on the road to where he would be crucified...<br /><br /> &quot;The Passion of the Christ&quot; was one of the unexpected hits of the last year -- it had a tiny budget, a seemingly small fanbase, and was made strictly according to the Catholic New Testament. But it struck a chord in people -- not just the subject matter, but the fact that Gibson was so dedicated. Much to Hollywood's surprise, people raced to see the controversial flick.<br /><br /> While some accuse Gibson of revelling in the gore, with a little bit of thought his &quot;Passion&quot;'s point comes through. It's horrifying to imagine a person -- let alone an incarnate god -- going through such horrors. But when it is realized what the point of all that suffering was for, it becomes a work of beauty. The biggest problem would be that Gibson spent little time on the idea of Jesus being resurrected, which was the whole point.<br /><br /> Jim Caviezel gives a stunning performance as Jesus Christ. Whether it's trying to pray through Satan's prattling or speaking to Mary and John from the cross, Caviezel brings every scene to life. Morgenstern is low-key wonderful as the sorrowful mother who has to watch her son killed by inches. And the beautiful Belucci is equally outstanding as the horrified Magdalene.<br /><br /> Yes, it's in Aramaic and Latin. But if the language doesn't hold you back, the beauty of the script can shine through. And Gibson's direction is equally stunning, utilizing rapid camerawork and plenty of flashbacks to make Jesus's struggle even more poignant. At times -- the table scene -- it's more than slightly awkward. But it's easy to forget that by the next scene.<br /><br /> It's a shock. It's a controversy. It's a one-of-a-kind film, based on a part of our culture that was underrated by Hollywood. It's Gibson's dark, bloody &quot;Passion of the Christ,&quot; and if you can watch something with some serious gore and straight-to-the-heart acting, then this is a must-see.amaic and Latin. But if the language doesn't hold you back, the beauty of the script can shine through. And Gibson's direction is equally stunning, utilizing rapid camerawork and plenty of flashbacks to make Jesus's struggle even more poignant. At times -- the table scene -- it's more than slightly awkward. But it's easy to forget that by the next scene. <br />  <br /> It's a shock. It's a controversy. It's a one-of-a-kind film, based on a part of our culture that was underrated by Hollywood. It's Gibson's dark, bloody &quot;Passion of the Christ,&quot; and if you can watch something with some serious gore and straight-to-the-heart acting, then this is a must-see.

No longer would height, weight, sex, education, or physical strength be used to keep new recruits out of the Metropolitan Police Academy.  Hundreds of people who never dreamed of becoming police officers signed up immediately.  Naturally, the police completely freaked.  -opening prologue of Police Academy.<br /><br />OK, so this is dated in terms of style and the chauvinism rampant in 80's comedies, but seeing it again for the first time in nearly twenty years brought back some nostalgic memories.  Granted, it's not an all-time classic, but hey, at least it's not as raunchy as American Pie.<br /><br />Diehards of the old school like academy chief and Lieutenant Thaddeus Harris work on a plan to make things tough for the new recruits, not by throwing them out but to make their training so miserable, they'll quit on their own accord.  Harris handpicks a Mutt-and-Jeff pair (both with crewcuts, no less) named Copeland and Blankes to help him weed out the scumbuckets, dirtbags, or whatever unpleasant name he has for the other recruits.  Yes, they'll learn about firearms, local laws, police procedure, and many many other things.  Well, it's mainly the first and last that happen in this classic 80's comedy.<br /><br />Then again, they were up against the likes of Carey Mahoney, the Monsignor Larvelle Jones, the suave lounge lizard George Martine, Leslie Barbara, Doug Fackler, and Tackleberry.  Mahoney is the main character and he's at the Academy as part of a deal with his friend Captain Reed, of a choice between the academy or the lockup for another minor offense.  And he can't quit as part of the deal-hence he tries to get himself kicked out by his antics.  For the most part, the main victim is Lieutenant Harris. The funniest moment involves Harris, a borrowed motorcycle, a parked car, and Harris flying into the air towards the rear end of a horse.  To which Mahoney says, \\"Someone call a veterinarian!\\"  Basically, some of the plot involves Mahoney pulling a prank on Harris, and either being called to Harris's office or being forced to do punitive exercises supervised by Harris or his handpicked student squad leaders, Copeland and Blankes.  However, Mahoney plays a real nasty and funny trick on those two involving the innocuously named Blue Oyster Bar.  And as for Commandant Lassard, that involves a funny moment at a podium.<br /><br />Larvelle Jones has to be my favourite character here.  He has an uncanny gift for sound effects, and when he and Mahoney first meet at the police station waiting room, he demonstrates his ability by imitating a machine gun.  Another one has him imitating the squishing sounds shoes make as the inspecting officer walks past the row of recruits on the academy lawn.<br /><br />Mahoney's roommate, Tackleberry, is a gung-ho type who wouldn't be out of place in Vietnam.  Call him a more comic version of Animal Mother in Full Metal Jacket.  He has guns that blow the heads off the firing range targets and his funniest moment involves the firearms drill, where he goes nuts.  When he says, \\"It's time this cop met the public,\\" watch out!<br /><br />But there are others.  Laverne Hooks, a short gentle black with a shy, timid voice, Doug Fackler, whose specialty is slapstick, mainly being clumsy at someone else's expense, Lesley Barbara, a chubby white guy and another timid soul, and Hightower, a quiet, towering black man who seems most likely to succeed, except for one thing that he needs help.  And this is one of Kim Cattrall's early films.  She plays Karen Thompson, Mahoney's love interest, at least when he's not asking her to bare her thighs.<br /><br />Steve Guttenberg (Mahoney), Michael Winslow (Jones), and David Graf (Tackleberry) boost this comedy, as does G.W. Bailey (Harris).  But the others are good too.  This is the best of the seven movie series.  Unfortunately, it all wentdownhill from there.ely, it all went downhill from there.
0792842499|4.0|Clint Eastwood and Lee van Cleef return in this third film which follows A FISTFUL OF DOLLARS (1964) and FOR A FEW DOLLARS MORE (1966). Eli Wallach as &quot;Tuco&quot; is the ugly one. 6305426694|5.0|Sometime in the late 1960's, a hideous act of pollution took place in Woburn, Massachusetts, a small town north of Boston.  Over the next fifteen years, twelve people died of leukemia.  Eight of those were children.  The firm of Jan Schlichtmann, Kevin Conway, James Gordon, and Bill Crowley take on the case on behalf of Anne Anderson, a woman who lost her child to cancer.  For her, money isn't the point.  All she wants to know is what happened, and for the responsible parties to come over and apologize to her and the other families.  Thing is, corporations apologize with money, and if the corporations have deep pockets, it's a case worth taking, so money does indeed become the point in A Civil Action.<br /><br />Schlichtmann uncovers the culprits, a chemical company, WR Grace and Beatrice Foods, who provide services for a tanning company owned by Riley.  With that, he files a lawsuit, the legal equivalent to a declaration of war, and hires a geological team to provide scientific evidence should it come to trial.<br /><br />Jan then does a couple things that leads to his downfall.  One, he gets personally involved.  In a news broadcast, he holds up snaps of the Woburn kids who have died.  He shows empathy, which is a grave disservice to the legal profession because it clouds his judgment.  He says it's like a doctor recoiling at the sight of blood.  That leads to his demanding of WR Grace and Beatrice Foods a multi-million dollar settlement, including money for a research foundation, to cover expenses, and to provide for the families for thirty years, which the corporations refuse, which in turn takes the case to trial.  He does this without consulting his partners, which doesn't bode well.  James Gordon, the accountant, points out that they need to work on other cases to provide a cash flow.  Schlichtmann has sunken a million into the Woburn case, and pretty soon, they teeter on the waterfalls of insolvency to the point of mortaging their homes.  It's become a source of pride, which has undone many an attorney as opposed to idiot witnesses, lousy evidence, and the hanging judge put together, as Jerome Fasher tells his law class.<br /><br />Fasher, the attorney for Beatrice, is a statesman-like man of experience, but has a detached air coupled with some eccentricities.  Yet he is a clever man, and his observation on the justice system is true, at times sickening.  When Schlichtmann tells him he's searching for the truth, he tells him, \\"You've been around long enough to know that a courtroom's not the place to look for the truth.\\"  And he accurately says that the case stopped being about children the moment Schlichtmann filed for action.<br /><br />The movie is sprinkled with legal commentary from Schlichtmann, which lays out how callous, ugly, and illogical the justice system is.  He begins by talking about which types of clients are worth more, i.e. are winning cases.  Whites are worth more than blacks, men more than women, a long agonizing death over a quick one.  A white male professional in his 40's, in his prime, is worth the most.  A dead child is worth least of all.  Well, Schlichtmann finds out that children are worth something after all, especially when he imagines an agonizing scene where the LaFierros were taking their son to the hospital and died en route.<br /><br />While John Travolta's best known for Grease and Saturday Night Fever, A Civil Action proves he can handle serious drama and he turns in one of his best ever performances.  However, the real Jan Schlichtmann came to Farmington.  He's close to seven feet tall, and in terms of resemblance, could've been played by Richard Gere.  As Anne Anderson, Kathleen Quinlan is the other great performer, playing a woman changed through her ordeal into someone who has a tired and sad visage.  The scene where Al Love (James Gandolfini), a conscience-stricken tannery employer personally apologizes to her shows that maybe the only real meaningful apologies come from humans, not corporations.<br /><br />Trials and lawsuits are examples of how corrupt and rotten the legal system and some lawyers are.  Is it worth having a system where the first party to come to their senses (i.e. to cut their losses and call for a settlement) is the loser?  A Civil Action also shows that despite the need for compassion, it's better to have a lawyer who thinks more with the head than the heart.rom humans, not corporations. <br /> <br />Trials and lawsuits are examples of how corrupt and rotten the legal system and some lawyers are.  Is it worth having a system where the first party to come to their senses (i.e. to cut their losses and call for a settlement) is the loser?  A Civil Action also shows that despite the need for compassion, it's better to have a lawyer who thinks more with the head than the heart.

I also thought that having Hell-boy miscalculate a jump between buildings was wonderful.  In the Matrix, Spiderman, etc characters are always capable of great leaps (both physical, mental, and social) but never over or undercalculate.  I would have actually given it a 3.5-star rating, but I can't with this rating system.  It loses points for lack of development for the evil characters and plot simplicity (I'm not always tired out and in search of simple action).  All in all a good movie and well-worth buying.

0671027387|4.0|I read this book after I read The Da Vince Code and before I read Angels and Demons... while it didn't stack up to the other two, it was certainly worth my time.  Deception Point was a great break from Tom Clancy and the like... the plot is a bit far-fetched, but that's ok, as it's fiction, and it's fun.  I'm tired of reading the reviews of all of the detail-cops out there... if you're going to read a fictional thriller, then you need to be prepared for a bit of literarly license.  What was great about this book, was that it tackled an area not usually covered with much success by fiction authors... NASA (and through it, subjects relating to space).  Usually a topic like this would be relegated to dollar store sci-fi, but Dan Brown does an excellent job of weaving Clancyesque political themes in with NASA coverups and suspenseful military operations.  When you pick this one up, make sure you are not expecting plots similar to Brown's two more famous tales.. this one's totally different.. but do not fear, it's certainly well worth the money, and you likely won't want to put it down!

B0000041BX|5.0|The Quartetto Italiano (Le Quartet Italien) have produced a bunch of excellent albums through the years, but among others this one stands out as a crucial release. This is one of the most celebrated recordings of Schubert's late quartets and for some good reasons. Here they introduce one of the finest 'Death and the Maiden' on disc. Although the competition is huge, it remains a refined and enlivened performance that has special merits. Of course, vintage versions by the Busch Quartet and also by the Juilliard String Quartet are steady references the Quartetto will be forgiven for not completely achieving. The Busch Quartet, especially, is still unsurpassed in this domain. The Quartetto's dazzling Quartet in G is equally splendid, as does the Quartettsatz. The music has guts with no compromise on harmonic detail and elegance. The overall clarity of sound and delineation of instruments are striking. Comparatively, the Brandis Quartet -with a particularly excellent 'Rosamunde'- suffers a bit from a slightly harsh top end (violin) that contrasts with the warmer and more disciplined string tone present on the Quartetto Italiano's recording. The Brandis is, sonics aside, a very good set of the quartets even so it can't match the Quartetto in most areas (except, perhaps, for the shimmering 'Rosamunde'). There are plenty of superb recordings of those works, especially the 'Maiden', including (among the names to watch): The Auryn Quartet, Verdi Quartet, Amadeus Quartet, Budapest Quartet, Melos Quartet, Leipzig String Quartet, Alban Berg Quartet, Aria Quartet, Petersen Quartet, Guarneri String Quartet, as well as the famous Emerson Quartet. You can't go wrong with any of them. The Quartetto Italiano belongs to this category, and sometimes it can and effectively does even surpass one or another in a few minor areas. A great package, imbued with a nice touch of quality a la Philips Classics.
B000002UAX|5.0|Their record producer - George Martin - felt and continues to say to this day that the Beatles should have culled the best dozen songs on this double LP and issued one great album.<br /><br /> I disagree.<br /><br /> John Lennon publicly stated that recording Sgt Pepper's was the happiest and perhaps most creative time he enjoyed during his \\"career\\" with the Beatles. Some have speculated that Sgt Pepper's was so good - so earth shatteringly good..! - and so important that they had nowhere to go but down after that.<br /><br />For 99.9% of the musicians / song writers / composers on the planet, I would be inclined to agree with this. But in this instance, we're talking about the Beatles. And the normal rules re creativity simply didn't apply to these guys.<br /><br />The White Album shows some of the cracks that would later result in the breakup of the band. If Sgt Pepper was the incredible result of four guys working as the world's greatest band, the White Album felt like four guys working individually.<br /><br />But notwithstanding the above, this is still a great album where many of the songs took their genesis during the Beatles stay in India. And there's some wonderful anecdotal stories that come to life re many of the great songs on this LP which make the songs even more \\"listenable\\".<br /><br />MIke Love of the Beach Boys, for example, was staying at the same compound at Rishikesh, India listening to the Maharishi. Do you think maybe \\"Back In The USSR\\" might have evolved from a conversation /influence that Mike and Paul might have had..?<br /><br /> \\"Sexy Sadie\\" is another one of those wonderful songs that only John Lennon can write so well. This song is directly solely at the Maharashi, who is \\"Sexy Sadie\\" who happened to \\"make a fool of everyone\\".<br /><br /> \\"The Continuing Story of Bungalow Bill\\" concerned a wealthy, young Ivy league type guy who happened to be there with his mother. Here's this idiot supposedly studying TM in this idyllic setting and when he has a couple of spare hours, he's out tiger hunting. And the story goes that while the other three Beatles were polite to this fellow when they would bump into him, John never masked his dislike of this fellow who got off killing tigers.<br /><br /> \\"While My Guitar Gently Weeps\\" provides another great story. During one particularly difficult time, George decided to invite his friend, Eric Clapton, into the studio to play on this new and great Harrison composition. Of course, Clapton initially protested saying \\"that nobody but the Beatles plays on Beatles albums - it just wasn't done\\". Well, Harrison convinced Eric that it was OK and while he was in the studio for hour after hour, all of the Beatles were on their very best behaviour, not wanting to \\"air their dirty laundry\\" to others.<br /><br /> Julia, Yer Blues. Revolution, Happiness Is A Warm Gun, Glass Onion are all great songs as well and certainly worthy of inclusion on any Beatles album.<br /><br /> When they do write individually, it's very interesting to see just how different Paul and John are in terms of their creative results.<br /><br /> Personally, I would be embarressed to have my name associated with something like Ob La Di Ob La Da, which is something only Paul Mc Cartney could have written. I Will and Martha My Dear are nice songs with very nice melodies.<br /><br /> Conversely, Happiness Is A Warm Gun, which was inspired by a magazine article that John read could only have originated in the mind of John Lennon. This and Revolution, for example, could never have been written by Paul.<br /><br /> When this album was originally released, it was indeed a very rare treat to receive two albums by the Beatles at that time. And notwithstanding a couple of weak effots that I usually just skip i.e. Why Don't We Do It In The Road, this album still provides a snapshot of the world's most important and creative band doing what they do best.. And the story goes that while the other three Beatles were polite to this fellow when they would bump into him, John never masked his dislike of this fellow who got off killing tigers.      \\"While My Guitar Gently Weeps\\" provides another great story. During one particularly difficult time, George decided to invite his friend, Eric Clapton, into the studio to play on this new and great Harrison composition. Of course, Clapton initially protested saying \\"that nobody but the Beatles plays on Beatles albums - it just wasn't done\\". Well, Harrison convinced Eric that it was OK and while he was in the studio for hour after hour, all of the Beatles were on their very best behaviour, not wanting to \\"air their dirty laundry\\" to others.      Julia, Yer Blues. Revolution, Happiness Is A Warm Gun, Glass Onion are all great songs as well and certainly worthy of inclusion on any Beatles album.      When they do write individually, it's very interesting to see just how different Paul and John are in terms of their creative results. I Will and Martha My Dear are nice songs with very nice melodies.      Conversely, Happiness Is A Warm Gun, which was inspired by a magazine article that John read could only have originated in the mind of John Lennon. This and Revolution, for example, could never have been written by Paul.       When this album was originally released, it was indeed a very rare treat to receive two albums by the Beatles at that time. B000008M54|5.0|It is no small wonder that a song as raw and charming as this album's brilliant title track was recorded in the 80s, a decade of such excess and tasteless production as to have permanently altered the landscape of the music industry. Yet, for all the sideshows that passed for &quot;music&quot; throughout those years of awful haircuts and clown makeup, this album sounds conspicuously like the real thing: a festival of acoustic guitars, accordions, organs, fiddles and slide-mandolins lifted to the heavens on the glories of Mike Scott's unmistakable vocals. No one can say &quot;whooo-hooo!&quot; with as much conviction as that man, hooting, hollering and scraping his way through the beautifully bombastic &quot;We Will Not Be Lovers&quot; and the piano-hysterical &quot;World Party.&quot; Opening as it does with four consecutive masterpieces, this album joins another Irish triumph, U2's &quot;The Joshua Tree,&quot; as one of the most perfectly sequenced albums in rock history -- up there with Dylan's &quot;Blood on the Tracks&quot; or Lou Reed's &quot;New York.&quot; Though the album's momentum slows gradually with the progessively bland &quot;Sweet Thing&quot; and &quot;Has Anybody Here Seen Hank,&quot; it never loses sight of its muse. Tunes like &quot;The Stolen Child&quot; or &quot;Strange Boat,&quot; while hardly the album's most interesting compositions, still command a clarity and urgency almost unheard of throughout the decade from which they so improbably emerged. &quot;Fisherman's Blues&quot; is that rare thing: an album that smacks of as much relevance and power today as it did the day it was released.
B000002UAU|5.0|I honestly don't know if Sgt Pepper's Lonely Heartls Club Band is the BEST album ever recorded. When you listen to the White Album or Revolver or Abbey Road, for example, they're all masterpieces that stand head and shoulders above anything else anybody else has ever done and you could make a compelling argument why one of these albums should hold this title.<br /><br /> But I will throw this out for your consideration. Sgt Pepper is the MOST important album ever made.<br /><br /> I was in my late teens in the summer of 1967 when this album was released and nobody had ever heard anything like it at the time. I recall travelling around the USA on my motorcyle that summer and it didn't matter where you were - a small town in Kansas, mid town Manhattan, Haight Ashbury - you would constantly hear the sounds of Sgt Pepper in the air. I remember reading comments by great recording artists who were also incredibly good and popular at the time thinking &quot;how on earth are we going to come up with something that can even hold a candle to this&quot;.<br /><br /> It was that good..!!<br /><br /> But it shouldn't have taken anybody by surprise.<br /><br /> You could see this tour-de-force coming after the release of the Beatles previous two gems - Rubber Soul and Revolver. And if there was any doubt as to the seemingly limitless creative abilities of these four guys, Penny Lane and the remarkable John Lennon postcard &quot;Strawberry Fields Forever&quot;, which were released just prior to Sgt Peppers, put any doubts to rest.<br /><br /> Even now, it blows my mind to think that in just three to four years, these guys went from composing and singing songs about &quot;I Want To Hold Your Hand&quot; and &quot;She Loves You&quot; to A Day In The Life, which may be the very best rock song ever composed. Period and end of argument. There just seemed to be no limits to The Beatles.<br /><br /> Sgt Peppper becomes an even more interesting album when you start to read and hear some of the anecdotal tidbits associated with it.<br /><br /> For eample, the Beatles made a video on the outskirts of a small English town to promote Strawberry Fields. During their stay, John Lennon was browsing through an old antiques store and happened to purchase an old Victorian poster that was all about a circus complete with a &quot;dancing horse&quot; and Pablo Fanque, etc. Of course, this poster became the wonderful &quot;For the Benefit of Mr Kite&quot;.<br /><br /> John was also an addicted TV watcher and minutes after seeing a televison commercial about Kelloggs Corn Flakes composed &quot;Good Morning, Good Morning&quot;.<br /><br /> But the tour de force on this album is the brilliant A Day In The Life. John was also an avid reader who would buy all of the London newspapers and read them from cover to cover. In one paper, he happened to read stories about the Guiness heir who died in an automobile accident (&quot;he blew his mind out in a car&quot;), alot of pot holes in the roads in one northern English town (&quot;4,000 holes in Blackburn, Lancashire&quot;), etc.<br /><br /> The problem was he wrote a beginning and end. But no middle. Concurrently, Paul had the makings of a middle eight section (&quot;woke up/ got out of bed / dragged a comb across my head&quot;) and nothing else. At a time when Lennon / McCartney collaberations were rarely, if ever, collaberations anymore (they continued to give joint credit, however, songs that were sung by Paul were Paul's songs and songs that John sang were songs that he wrote). However, in this instance, they were able to merge their &quot;songs&quot; to produce this masterpiece which, in my opinion, is the best song ever and for this reason alone may entitle Sgt Pepper to lay claim to the best rock album ever.<br /><br /> One thing I've never bought into concerns Paul's idea that this was a &quot;concept album&quot;. In other words, the Beatles would &quot;transform&quot; themselves into another band, which would makethis album. Aside from the title song and the reprise just prior to a Day In The Life, every other song is a &quot;stand alone&quot; song that could just as easily have appeared on any other Beatles album.<br /><br /> But this in no way detracts from this incredible album.<br /><br /> Simply put, this album changed the way rock musicians saw themselves and the way music was made thereafter.<br /><br /> This is the most important album ever made by four guys who merely changed the world.s into another band, which would make this album. B00006M183|4.0|After the aimlessness and indifference of &quot;Binaural,&quot; the band's lowest moment, PJ returns to the tighter structures and patience that made &quot;Yield&quot; one of their most engaging albums. Riot Act also boasts something of a newer direction for the band, and it is thus no surprise that critics are beginning to reevaluate Pearl Jam outside of the &quot;grunge&quot; mantle under which they were ushered so hastily. Only 1996's &quot;No Code&quot; starts off on a quieter note than Riot Act's haunting and eloquent &quot;Can't Keep&quot; which, ironically, is every bit as powerful a launching pad as more raucous openers such as &quot;Go&quot; or &quot;Brain of J.&quot; Much like &quot;No Code,&quot; Riot Act is full of a kind of intrigue and risk that Pearl Jam displays only ocassionally. The gritty groove of &quot;You Are&quot; has the sound of a great hip-hop beat overlaid with some good old snotty rock 'n roll. Though Vedder's lyrics frequently leave a lot to be desired here (&quot;Love is a tower/And you're the Key&quot; or &quot;First comes love, then comes pain/Let the games begin&quot;) Riot Act's searing musical dexterity ultimately wins out. The rollicking &quot;Green Disease&quot; sounds like the first track of the next Strokes album, while the gorgeous &quot;Thumbing My Way&quot; nearly steals the show with its tender plainspokenness. The guitar-roasting tandem of Gossard and Mcreedy is as loose as ever on the glorious &quot;1/2 Full&quot; and its wailing solos. Yet the album's most captivating moment comes with the band's greatest departure from its sound, as Vedder bellows commandingly through the brief &quot;Arc,&quot; a revisitation of his interest in middle-eastern sounds that ushers in the ambient and dark closer, &quot;All or None.&quot; These songs run laps around just about anything Binaural served up. But as even that subpar effort delivered a few gems in &quot;Of the Girl,&quot; &quot;Nothing as it Seems&quot; and &quot;Breakerfall,&quot; Riot Act is more proof that this is one of the few bands that fans can count on to deliver at least a handful of classics on every release. Whether they take time to grow on you or grab you by the throat upon the first listen, the result is usually the same: a wild gratitude.t; Riot Act is more proof that this is one of the few bands that fans can count on to deliver at least a handful of classics on every release. Whether they take time to grow on you or grab you by the throat upon the first listen, the result is usually the same: a wild gratitude.
