B00007LTIB|5.0|\\"Relayer\\" along with \\"Tales From Topographic Oceans\\", \\"Fragile\\" and \\"Close To The Edge\\" is the best of the 1970s Yes and my perhaps my favorite Yes album. Theres some truly amazing playing by everybody involved on this one. Patrick Moraz's keyboards are refreshingly different, more jazzy and really blend in well with the band. What a shame that they kicked him out after this one album. Steve Howe plays with a savagery and abandon I've never heard him play with before or since, he's remarkable. Fantastic drumming by Alan White. I think Alan came into his own on this release. Chris Squire's bass playing is wonderfullly nimble, almost jazzy, yet still retains a lot of rock muscle.  Jon Anderson's vocals are impeccable, and the lyrics which actually make sense are at times quite moving.<br /><br /> The album starts with \\"The Gates Of Delerium\\" a song that depicts musically the start, middle and end of a battle. The middle section is the most violent Yes I've ever heard as they imitate the clash of swords and the chaos of war. The final part of Gates of Delerium, the sad aftermath of the battle is breathtaking in its emotional impact. I can't praise Moraz keyboards enough. He blends perfectly with the other guys and adds considerable atmosphere. The next song \\"Sound Chaser\\" is aptly named. Its an insane, mostly instrumental workout that sounds like \\"Close To The Edge\\" meets Mahavishnu Orchestra. Its a savage, though jazz-like rock masterpiece with some truly spastic guitar and drums. In the middle of the piece is a solo distorted electric guitar interlude that is a melding of classical with rock electricity. That's followed by some almost funky, yet sizzlingly fast jazz rock keyboard pyrotechnics by Pat Moraz. This song has odd changes of meter and tempo, wicked solos, some tribal chanting and just cooks. The last song \\"To Be Over\\" is quite simply one of the most beautiful things Yes has ever done. Its delicate yet strong and is a welcome respite after the assault of the previous two songs. There is some fine guitar from Steve Howe and wonderfully subtle keyboards from Patrick Moraz. The song builds to a slow glorious vocal melody. Some very nice keys and guitar ensue and the song ends with two different repeating melodys played on guitar and sung that gradually fade out like a majestic sunset changing to purple night.<br /><br /> Relayer is one of best and most unique albums in Yes' discography. Due in large part to Patrick Moraz' keyboards, it contains some of Yes most spirited almost violent playing. If you like \\"Close to the Edge\\" or \\"Tales From Topographic Oceans\\" you will most probably like this album.us two songs. There is some fine guitar from Steve Howe and wonderfully subtle keyboards from Patrick Moraz. The song builds to a slow glorious vocal melody. Some very nice keys and guitar ensue and the song ends with two different repeating melodys played on guitar and sung that gradually fade out like a majestic sunset changing to purple night.       Relayer is one of best and most unique albums in Yes' discography. Due in large part to Patrick Moraz' keyboards, it contains some of Yes most spirited almost violent playing. If you like \\"Close to the Edge\\" or \\"Tales From Topographic Oceans\\" you will most probably like this album.

B00009Z574|4.0|I don't understand why this album is so hated. No, its not a classic album but its close to being as good as their previous effort &quot;Going For The One.&quot; Theres a wealth of great playing on this album. There are complex, moving melodies, rocking guitar, bass and drums and the keyboards are in general well played throughout.<br /><br /> I always thought that on Tormato Yes tried to shift gears. They eschewed their trademark side long sonic excursions and like much of &quot;Going For The One&quot; wrote shorter, yet still progressive songs. And for the most part they succeeded: &quot;Future Times/Rejoice&quot;, &quot;Don't Kill The Whale&quot;, &quot;Release Release&quot;, and &quot;On the Silent Wings Of Freedom&quot; are all very good concise yet complex progressive rock songs. &quot;Madrigal&quot; and &quot;Onward&quot; are both very nice ballads with a good sense of relaxed mood or spacey atmosphere. &quot;Circus of Heaven&quot; isnt so hot, but isn't as wretched as some of the reviewers would have you believe. It's perhaps a bit too precious for my taste.<br /><br /> However, criticisms about the odd sound quality are for the most part valid. While the album is clear, its got a tinny, trebly sort of sheen to it. There's not much bottom end at all and the keyboard sounds that Wakeman uses are sometimes strange, as is the sound of Steve Howe's guitar. Quite simply put this album is sonically very different from Yes' previous output and perhaps this is why so many people seem to dislike it so much.<br /><br /> Overall though, I think Tormato is a good album. No, its not one of my favorite Yes albums. In terms of quality its in the middle of the pack. But it is perhaps one of the last truly progressive albums that Yes put out before becomming more pop oriented in the eighties. Its a transitional album, but has its own charms and is definitely worth having.

B00005QEO2|4.0|\\"Young Lust - The Aerosmith Anthology\\" chronicles Aerosmith's Geffen-years from the mid-eighties onward.  Gathering 34 singles, album tracks and live cuts, it offers a fine retrospective, and it manages to include almost all of the best songs from Aerosmith's last six studio albums. This is pretty much all that the casual fan will need.    Having said that, I would have preferred a leaner version of \\"Amazing\\" to the orchestrated one included here, but the acoustic rendition of the hit \\"Livin' On The Edge\\" is really good, and Run-DMC's take on the sublime hard rock song \\"Walk This Way\\" is included, too.   The live versions of \\"Dream On\\" and \\"Sweet Emotion\\" are sort of pointless, though, and those two should have been left off in favour of two or three more songs from the band's Geffen years, but the selection is generally very good, and small flaws like those I just mentioned don't really ruin the overall impression.     The MTV-staples \\"Dude (looks like a lady)\\" and \\"Love In An Elevator\\" are here, as well as power ballads like \\"Angel\\", \\"Cryin'\\", and \\"Crazy\\", the underrated blues shuffle \\"Hangman Jury\\", the melodic (and disturbing) \\"Janie's Got A Gun\\", and several other smashes like \\"The Other Side\\", \\"What It Takes\\", and the hard rockers \\"Eat The Rich\\", \\"Head First\\", \\"Let The Music Do The Talking\\", \\"Rag Doll\\", and \\"My Fist Your Face\\".   \\"Young Lust\\" also includes and excellent version of the Door's \\"Love Me Two Times\\", as well as \\"Deuces Are Wild\\", \\"Blind Man\\" and \\"Walk On Water\\", the three previously unreleased songs from Aerosmith's earlier Geffen compilation, \\"Big Ones\\".     This well-annotated double disc compilation is the best available overview of Aerosmith's latter-day output. Get this one, and the excellent box set \\"Pandora's Box\\" for the 'Smith's seventies classics, and you're set!

B000001EEN|5.0|This, to me, is one of the most curiously overlooked and underrated live albums of the 70s. Ever, actually.   I know that not everyone shares my fondness for Eric Clapton the bluesman-slash-rock singer rather than Eric Clapton the balladeer-slash-watered-down-blues-singer, but I remain convinced that this is one of the three or four greatest records Clapton has ever released.      \\"Eric Clapton's Rainbow Concert\\" is not a polished, highly produced affair; it is all gritty rock n' roll and smouldering blues, and Clapton is backed by star players like Pete Townshend, Ron Wood and Steve Winwood, and guest percussionist Rebop Kwaku Baah. And this all-star band, which has former Traffic-drummer Jim Capaldi on the swivel chair and the late Rick Gretch playing bass, leads Clapton through a dozen raw, ragged and superbly atmospheric renditions of his best songs of the 60s and 70s, including \\"Layla\\", \\"Bell Bottom Blues\\", \\"Key To The Highway\\" and \\"Blues Power\\".    Eric Clapton and the band play with passion and urgency, and Clapton himself sounds much more alive than on most live recordings.   If you like Eric Clapton at his grittiest, it doesn't get any better than this.

0553277472|1.0|This nonsense has to end now.      Like many of you, a wild-eyed friend recommended this book to me. I had heard so many good things, I was stunned at how awful it was.     The books ends with him sitting cross-legged and naked on the floor, catatonic, sitting in his own urine, with a cigarette burning down to his knuckles. His wife (wisely) calls the authorities to take him away and receive electroshock treatment. His son asks, \\"Were you insane?\\" He cries out, \\"No!\\" To his son, and to us.    The entire book is an attempt to say that rather than being mentally ill, he is simply a free-thinker, and sees the world differently.     Many, many readers pointed out how rambling the narrative is, and how illogical his reasoning is (and this from the ones who liked the book!) Other symptoms of his illness: anyone who disagreed with him had a secret motive, or they couldn't see the \\"truth.\\"    He's absolutely furious at being forced to endure shock treatments and outraged at being labeled \\"insane,\\" but he was (at one time) severely mentally ill, and trying to deal with that. That's HIS journey. Yours is not to get caught up in the \\"depth\\" of this book as if it means anything. It doesn't.   Do NOT follow a madman, do NOT support his illness by buying or recommending this book, and please, please, take a moment to feel sorry for his traumatized son.

B0002IQJUK|5.0|Gavin DeGraw is one of those artists you need to see live to really appreciate. The man can put on a show that will knock your socks off. His album &quot;Chariot&quot; is a main source of material for these live shows, as well as any number of incredible soul-filled covers.       On &quot;Chariot Stripped&quot;, DeGraw heads back into the studio to re-record the album that put him on the map, but gives each song a &quot;live&quot; feel by taking a bare-bones approach to each song. The result is an album that leaves the listener with a sense of having actually just seen the artist live.       With so many bands intent on releasing live albums of their best material, it's refreshing to see one take those same songs and record them with the sound clarity that only a studio can provide. DeGraw's voice has such a distinct, gritty sound that each track gets taken to a level that might normally get lost in the clean-up production phase of an album.       With the new spin on these tracks you get the rawest, most emotional forms of already great songs that have been further tweaked and perfected on the road.       As an added bonus, the album includes an amazing cover of &quot;Change is Gonna Come&quot; by Sam Cooke that will leave you speechless. Degraw has gained a reputation for delivering some of the most inspired covers of Motown classics to come along in years, and this track proves why. He belts out the lyrics as if he wrote them himself and pulls the listener through the roller coaster of his vocal range along the way.       All in all, this is a great deal for a two-cd set and it just gets better with each listen. Tell all your friends to watch out for this artist, because he's gaining momentum as his popularity grows and has the potential to be a household name.

It was carefully constructed and absolutely requires repeated viewings to understand it (what could be better in a DVD than a movie that you have to watch over and over again to understand everything?). <br />  <br /> In any event, let me give a hint to anyone interested in understanding the movie. After the initial shot of a jitterbug competition, we see the main character of the movie. A minute later, we see someone falling asleep into red covers on a bed (don't see the person, but we see it from the person's point of view). The next two hours of the movie are a dream. <br />  <br /> After about two hours, the main character, Diane Selwyn, wakes up from her dream. You know this because she wakes up from the same red covers that she fell asleep on (in the first few minutes of the move). <br />  <br /> Diane has mental problems relating to her being spurned by her lesbian lover Camilla Rhodes (Camilla is in love with a man, but also seems to like the lesbian scene - just not with Diane anymore). So, Diane pays a hitman to have her killed, and supposedly, Camilla is killed. Diane is racked with guilt, mental problems and flashbacks of her time with Camilla. It is this mental breakdown and her hiring of a hitman, plus a scene where Camilla humilliates her at a party that make up the last thirty minutes of the film. <br />  <br /> There are many little details that I want to work out to completely understand the movie, but I definitely understand the most important parts. Here they are again. <br />  <br /> Main character is introduced at a jitterbug contest (real life, not fantasy). <br />  <br /> Main character falls asleep (dream -fantasy). <br />  <br /> Two hours of dream happen, andthe exact meaning of every detail cannot be completely explained, but many of the characters and situations make sense during the last half hour of the movie. <br />  <br /> Main character awakes (about 2 hours into the movie). This tells the real life story of Diane Selwyn and her hallucinations of Camilla. It also explains many of the characters in her dream, and her hiring of a hit man to kill Camilla.  <br />  <br /> I don't want to give a lot away, because I want people to view the movie many times to get an understanding of this movie. There are so many little and subtle details that will enhance this experience. <br />  <br /> It's a phenominal movie and it really does rate as one of the best ever. Believe me, it is not just a Lynchian thing that no one is meant to understand. There is a rhyme and reason to the movie, it just takes several viewings to understand. <br />  <br /> I will not put myself in a position of mentioning this movie with other great movies of the past (even though I think it is up there with the best movies of any age), but it is one of those movies that require, yes require, many viewings to get even a basic understanding of what is going on. <br />  <br /> Once again, the simplest synopsis of all. <br />  <br /> About 2 minutes into the movie the main character falls asleep. For the next two hours the main character has a dream. After that, the character awakes and we are given the details of how she arranged to have her lesbian lover killed. This is the most basic idea of what the movie is about. <br />  <br /> I have never experienced a movie as complex and understandable as this before. It is a classic and I guarantee that future viewers and reviewers will see it as such. Like I said before, it really is not a movie that is simply Lynchian and cannot be understood. I honestly don't think cinema gets better than this movie.  <br />  <br /> I don't suspect anyone will ever read this article, as it is somewhere around the 917th reviewof the movie, but hopefully, someone will find it useful.

Meaning no offense to Lacuna Coil (I like Linkin Park) they truly are Linkin Park with a female singer. B000003TA4|1.0|NIRVANA was too simple to become the area-rock band it morphed into over a period of one year. Nevermind is a testament to that. Teen Spirit was the smash-hit, but is so simple it's sad. I wish there was more to Nevermind than meets the eye, but there isn't. There's less. It's all a bunch of meaningless mumbled words with the slur of a junkie you'd come to expect. Lithium doesn't even have a chorus. Any of the lyrics to Cobain's songs are interchangable. He could sing and speak in tongues over an album (which he practically did every record he made), and fans would still eat it up with all the eagerness they can muster. Unplugged, sadly, is the best we'll ever know from Cobain. His stupid &quot;punk ethos&quot; (and drug afflicted addiction) got in the way of his creativity.

B0000035E7|2.0|Bleach is an accurate refection of what NIRVANA was, and how each member plays off the others. The album (from a musicianship standpoint) is nothing close to great, but I think it's commendable the band shows its true self on their debut. On Bleach, NIRVANA weren't trying to be Punk by spending only $600 on making the album; they did it out of necessity because they had no other choice. And for what it is, the album is worth a few listens. First off, the sound quality is great. I would have never known it cost so little if it weren't for that proud little blurb at the bottom of the back of the record cover stating so. That shows NIRVANA was once resourceful, which is nice to see. It's a shame Kurt Cobain went for expensive overproduction on Nevermind to make the band sound better than they really were. It's also a shame Kurt paid for expensive computer-trickery on In Utero to digitally and electronically alter the songs to make them sound harsher than they really were (hint: it's most obvious on his screams on &quot;Scentless Apprentice&quot;). As for the Bleach songs, well, there's a great solo in &quot;Blew&quot; but the rest of the song sucks. The standout songs for me were &quot;Scoff&quot; and &quot;Sifting&quot;. Too bad the band didn't have any slower, more pounding tracks on Nevermind or In Utero. The closest NIRVANA ever came to capturing the pounding rhythm of Bleach was on 1992's Incesticide compilation where songs date back to the 1/23/88 session with Dale Crover. And I must say, &quot;Big Long Now&quot; is the mother of all NIRVANA songs.       3.5 stars out of 5

Essaywhuman?!!!??! and Lazy Afternoon are some pretty funky/cool songs. Lazy Afternoon is a track you could chill and blaze an L to. <br /> <br />I give this album 5 stars because Black Thought and Malik B put it down lyrically. Thought drops some classic verses on this CD. Beats are kind of jazzy but still mainly influenced by hip-hop. The beats pretty much are typical Roots work. I reccomend it to true hip-hop heads who have been peepin The Roots before the last 2 albums have come out. If you like Mos Def, Common, Talib Kweli or Guru's solo stuff then this is for you.

I really love the Chariot (track 2 again) acoustic version because he releases so much emotion and you can feel what he was thinking when he wrote the song. Gavin does a fantastic job of portraying his thoughts in his ALL self-written masterpieces. Buy it soon, because it is limited in number (comes with original and acoustic, so VERY worth your money). Great voice. Fantastic range. Many different styles throughout the album. Several different life topics. He conveys every emotion and dramatic detail of his life experiences. Easy to relate to. Makes you want to sing along and never stop listening! GREAT. OUTSTANDING. BEAUTIFUL. In other words...very Gavin-esque.
B000003TAR|1.0|NIRVANA's In Utero is one of the most pretentious, artsy-fartsy albums I've ever had the displeasure of owning. I mean, just look at the awful inlay design! Bleach has a better sound quality than In Utero, hands down. Cobain and the boys wrung very drop of sound quality they could muster out of that $600 dollars. Everything on In Utero just sounds distant and mushy. Most of the songs don't even feature bass. Well, I'm sure they do, but it's inaudible to the human ear because of Albini felt the need to be &quot;Punk&quot; and attempt to live up to others' standards and try to prove his &quot;noize maven&quot; status once again. In Utero got its cheap sound in a very un-punk and pricey way; the band opted to electronically treat Kurt's screams on several songs so they wouldn't sound as good as Kurt really did sound in the studio. They basically sucked the natural talent and beauty out of Kurt's voice and had a computer make his voice scratchier than normal.

B000066NW0|4.0|Much controversy arose surrounding the debut of Canadian singer Avril Lavigne. Many people were outraged when Avril's 2002 debut was not a \\"punk\\" album as many claimed it was. As I can recall, Avril herself never claimed to be a punk singer. It was merely a stereotype placed on her since she played guitar and skateboarded. As for rumours regarding whether or not Avril is capable of either of these activities, whether or not Avril herself plays an instrument (and she does in fact play keyboard and guitar as shown on recent performances) is not too big an issue since Avril has a band that plays while she sings. I'm sure it is quite difficult to do both at once and many artists have bands rather than playing themselves. As for whether or not she skateboards, how does that affect her music?       The album opens with a band with the moody fourth single, \\"Losing Grip\\". It's a kind of pop-rock breakup song with great lyrics and a very good beat. They lyrics tell about the way Avril feels at the end of a bad relationship (\\"why should i care? cuz you weren't there when i weas scared. I was so alone.\\"). Avril's voice sounds great in this song as she sings about a relationship gone wrong. The extremely catchy \\"Complicated\\" comes next which talks about a boyfriend/friend who acts differently when they are alone with Avril and when they are with others. It is a very easy song to relate to and Avril sounds awesome in it. The second single, \\"Sk8r Boi\\" follows and it is a song about a girl who breaks up with her boyfriend because of what her friends say. (\\"But all of her friends, stuck up their nose\\") The lyrics are very simple but fit well with the song.       Afterwards comes \\"I'm With You\\", a touching and somewhat gloomy-sounding song (and third single) about loneliness and the need for a change of scenery. It is sung in a very compelling manner and the bridge is particularly strong. (\\"Why is everything so confusing? Maybe I'm just out of my mind\\"). \\"Mobile\\" comes next and seems to be about constantly moving and changing. It is not a personal favourite but it is still a quality song. After this comes \\"Unwanted\\", possibly the least memorable song on the album though it is in no way bad. It is stylistically closest to \\"Losing Grip\\". Avril sings about a love that always ignored her and about how she always tried to belong with him. The lyrics are very convincing and well-written. \\"Tomorrow\\", a mellower track and a personal favourite, follows. In it, Avril sings quietly and sweetly about not being ready to be with someone (after he hurt her?). It has touching lyrics and remarkable background music. (\\"And I want to believe you, when you tell me that it'll be ok, and I try to believe you but I don't.\\").       After that comes \\"Anything But Ordinary\\", a seemingly more personal song. In this one, Avril talks about not wanting to be just like everyone else. The lyrics are extremely simple but generally well-written and add a lot to the meaning of the song. Instead of sounding entirely childish, as this song could have, it shows a different side of Avril. However, it is far from the best song on the album. \\"Things I'll Never Say\\" comes next and seems to be about Avril trying to be perfect for the one she loves while giving the listeners insight about what she is thinking. (\\"If I could say what I wanna say, I'd say I wanna blow you away, be with you tonight...\\"). Her vocals match the style of this song incredibly. \\"My World\\" comes after which seems to be another more personal song. This one talks about growing up in a small town (Napanee). Like \\"Anything But Ordinary\\" the lyrics are a little less mature but convey the message of the song. However, it is not one of the better songs on the album mostly because of the somewhat weaker lyrics.       The final three songs are (to me) album highlights. \\"Nobody's Fool\\" is up first and in it, Avril kind of speaks the lyrics to a tune (rather than singing). Many people (myself included) have called this a kind of rap song but that is not entirely true. This song is one of the more meaningful ones on the album and talks about being yourself and not just agreeing to be whatever others tell you to be. After this comes a personal favourite, \\"Too Much To Ask\\". At one of her concerts, Avril mentioned that this song was written about a real life experience about a crush she had. There is something appealing about this song that I can't quite put my finger on. The lyrics are quite well-written and Avril's vocals are particularly good even though she does not do Christina-Aguilera-style vocal gymnastics. Finally, there is the last track entitled \\"Naked\\". This song is about finding someone who makes you feel figuratively naked, or as if you don't have to hide. (\\"I'm trying to remember why I was afraid, to be myself and let the covers fall away\\"). Most fans do not like this song however I think it has a good message and great vocals.       Overall Mark: 4/5       Overall, Avril Lavigne provided a solid debut containing many enjoyable songs. Though Avril may not be \\"punk\\" as many have labeled her, her album consists of songs ranging from straight pop (\\"Sk8r Boi\\") to pop-rock (\\"Losing Grip\\", \\"Unwanted\\"). Many people have commented that Avril was fed all of her material by her producers however if you take a look at the liner notes you will see that Avril co-wrote every song on the album. Also, whether or not Avril herself played the instruments in her songs, as I've mentioned before, does not matter as she has a band that plays instead and there is nothing wrong with that.

B000002JPA|5.0|Over the course of my life, I drew closer to heavy metal bands like Iron Maiden, Judas Priest, and early Metallica, while also finding lesser known but certainly ultimate bands like Arch Enemy, Nevermore, Iced Earth, and the like. From there, I got into Rush and discovered a whole new universe practically new to me at the time: progressive rock! I yearned for more and thanks to my friend (thanks, tkdmateo!), he pulled out a CD one day and it would become of the most important albums I've had the pleasure of listening to: &quot;Images and Words&quot; by Dream Theater. They had only released one album prior to this one in 1989 titled &quot;When Dream and Day Unite,&quot; but it wasn't until this album when the band got their sound tightly down and achieved a large fanbase.<br /><br /> At the time, the band consisted of James LaBrie (who just replaced original vocalist Charlie Dominici), guitar virtuoso John Petrucci, drummer Mike Portnoy, bassist John Myung, and keyboardist Kevin Moore. The band is certainly at their prime here, showing great technical skill and prowess with their instruments. The band has their own unique sound that's become quite influential, and in itself it is derived from Pink Floyd, Rush, Queensryche, and Metallica... talk about variety!<br /><br /> The first track and radio hit, Pull Me Under, is an awesome opener with excellent keyboards in the background. It maintains a midpaced structure that was infectious for me. Of course, I wanted to hear more, and then I heard Another Day. A ballad with James' vocals in tip-top shape... the guy can really sing! There's also a saxophone solo, which I quite liked (not for all tastes, but give it a chance). Track #3 is Take the Time, a MASSIVE rocker that just goes everywhere. It's progressive, unpredictable style is enthralling; it's so tightly structured and unbelievable. Surrounded is more of a melodic rocker with some fine guitarwork. It reminds me of early Genesis. And now... the next two tracks (my personal favorites)! Metropolis Part I: The Miracle and the Sleeper is an excellent epic-style track that's also very unpredictable. Dazzling work by all instruments, although James only sings a little bit in the song. Oh well. Still found it to be one of my top favorites. The other one, Under a Glass Moon, is a song that's a rare case; it rocks hard, yet it is also so intensely melodic and has an outer-space feel to it. What an achievement! Another track in which the keyboards dominate. Wait For Sleep, while a nice song, is a really short piano ballad. I wish the band could've spent more time on it, but oh well. The final track and also the album's longest, Learning to Live, is the disc's most optimistic track. This proves that when problems are addressed, they can be solved, which is something many bands neglect to write in their material. It's also the most technically proficient; the guitars and keyboards are at their finest here.<br /><br /> Overall, this is a masterpiece in the most serious sense. In my reviews, I usually don't mention people because I try to be at least half-professional when writing them. However, in this case, I owe my friend a great deal of gratitude (and also to all of you Amazon reviewers that praise the album) for not only exposing me to this awesome disc, but also for opening many new doors in the realm of progressive rock. My voyage in the genre continues even further....(my personal favorites)! Metropolis Part I: The Miracle and the Sleeper is an excellent epic-style track that's also very unpredictable. Dazzling work by all instruments, although James only sings a little bit in the song. Oh well. Still found it to be one of my top favorites. The other one, Under a Glass Moon, is a song that's a rare case; it rocks hard, yet it is also so intensely melodic and has an outer-space feel to it. What an achievement! Another track in which the keyboards dominate. Wait For Sleep, while a nice song, is a really short piano ballad. I wish the band could've spent more time on it, but oh well. The final track and also the album's longest, Learning to Live, is the disc's most optimistic track. This proves that when problems are addressed, they can be solved, which is something many bands neglect to write in their material. It's also the most technically proficient; the guitars and keyboards are at their finest here. <br />  <br /> Overall, this is a masterpiece in the most serious sense. In my reviews, I usually don't mention people because I try to be at least half-professional when writing them. However, in this case, I owe my friend a great deal of gratitude (and also to all of you Amazon reviewers that praise the album) for not only exposing me to this awesome disc, but also for opening many new doors in the realm of progressive rock. My voyage in the genre continues even further....

If you haven't seen it. Get It! Simply my favorite movie. Period. Better on DVD now with both standard TV and Widescreen on 2 sides. Simply one of the BEST SciFi Movies Ever Made!, July 23, 1997 Reviewer: A viewer  <br />  <br /> OOOhhhh! Fliping through the channels...surfing the cable and ...WOW! What is this? Cool! C57D, a flying saucer with, YES it's Leslie Nielsen as ever-so-serious Captain. <br /> Forbidden Planet, was MGM's high-budget, risky venture at making the one of the finest Color Sci-Fi classics in the 50's. Unlike many of the low budget movies of the genre, FP remains to this day a very entertaining and captivating film. I have to say, that it changed my life as a kid, because it gave me the desire to explore more books about Sci-Fi. Now, I am a Software Engineer with thousands of video tapes. Monster movies are my favorites, and speaking of monsters, the one in FP is on the top of my list of BEST MONSTERS (those you really don't want to ever meet in a dark...even a well lit alley). <br />  <br /> The story: Based on a screenplay by Irving Block and Allen Adler (Fatal Planet), it takes its inspiration from Shakespears's THE TEMPEST. In anutshell, Spacemen come to rescue a lost group of colonists, only to find that most have died long ago. Only Dr. Morbius (Walter Pidgeon) and his daughter Altaira (Anne Francis) remain. They tell Commander Adams (Leslie Nielsen) that 20 years ago, when they first landed, some invisible power killed everyone but Dr.Morbius and his wife (now deceased from natural causes). Soon, we find that the good Doctor has discovered that the KRELL, a once powerful race of aliens, lived below the surface of Altair-4 (where they are) and they created a machine that is 20x20x20 miles square (thats 8000 cubic miles of Klystrons and Relays...and they never stop self repairing themselves!). Well, before you know it, the Monster is back...and people are dying...and well, the big, bad disintigrator beams from the ship's main weapons are NOT stopping it! <br />  <br /> I must mention that this was the first movie with ROBBY THE ROBOT. ROBBY was based on Asimov's Robots Rules of order, and for the most part was just a big lovable teady-bear. He could never hurt anyone, but watch how Morbius proves this by having Robby point a &quot;BLASTER&quot; at the Commander! The way Nielsen clinches his fists was so telling!. <br />  <br /> The sets were beautiful, the saucer flys perfectly (notice the shadows and the dust when it lands). So much here that you simply must watch very closely to the detail, it really is worth it. Speaking of detail, the Monster was pretty easy...because it was MOSTLY invisible. Joshua Meador (on loan from Disney Studios) made the animation of the monster. It is crude by comparison to the new Computer Generated Animation (CGA), but for its time it was AWESOME! The monster, by the way, is powered by 2700 thermo-nuclear reactors, and can recreate itself, microsecond after microsecond! NO! IT CANNOT BE DESTROYED! (You thought ALIENS were tough! HAH!)  <br />  <br /> Well, there is a little love story going on with the Commander and Altaira, and Daddy doesn't like it. Go Figure! Anyway, I won't give it all away, just GET IT AND ENJOY!  <br />  <br /> ... END  <br />  <br />  <br />

B000068IEU|1.0|Wes Craven's first picture is a moronic, escessive and unintentionally humorous tale of revenge. The story focuses on two teenaged girls, who are kidnapped on their way to a rock concert by a gang of escaped convicts. The felons bring the two to the woods next to one of the girls' home,  raping and killing them both. After discovering the address to their victems' house, the guilty parties make a housecall. But the late girls' parents uncover the killers dark secret, and exact bloody revenge. Craven utterly fails to shock or disturb the viewer for two reasons; first the actors are unconvincing, and he inexplicable accompanies the scenes of bloodshed with cheerful music. The director also fails to establish the antagonists as the wicked, immoral convicts that they are. Instead they come off as innocent, misjugded people looking to start over. The script is also severly flawed, for example; when the criminals are spending the night at the victems' home, the parents become suspicious. The mother of the deceased, then looks in one of the killers bags, inside she sees a shirt covered in blood. Then she goes to the washroom and find one of the felons inside, this peticular man has the same necklace as her daughter. So for her, this is concrete evidence that these men residing under their roof have killed her daughter. Dashing out of the house, the mother and father, run into the forest and conveniently find their daughter's corps spawled on the ground. Now Suppose, the evidence was sufficient to assume their daughter was dead, why then would the parents impulsively run to the forest in search of her body? The parents revenge is equaly senseless. One of the convicts lets himself be seduced by the wife, after she convinces him to let her tie him up, she proceeds to give him oral sex, ultimately bitting off his penis. Now, the man's hands were tied, and it would have been easier and less emotionally damaging to have stabed him, but instead she castrates him whith her teeth.Perhaps Craven sees this as equal justice, but after that twisted act, you begin to view the felon with sympathy and the wife with comtempt. I believe and hope, that I have illustrated that this abomination is neither worth the time nor money that would be spent on the rental.

Not only is the book gripping while you are reading it but it stays with you afterwards, and now I can't stop thinking about it. This is the story of two teenagers who grow up next door to one another from birth, their parents are best friends and have always expected that their children will fall in love and marry each other one day. The book jumps from Chris and Emily's perspective as well as both sets of parents. The novel centers on a suicide pact gone awry and its terrible aftermath (as well as what has lead up to the central moment). There are some rather disturbing and poignant moments in the novel.<br /><br />  This is one of the most moving, touching, thought provoking and disarming books I have read. It certainly made me think about the lives of those around me. Read this wonderful gem, but make sure to keep a box of tissues nearby because this novel will touch you to the core.

0374384576|5.0|Roald Dahl's &quot;The Witches&quot; was highly recommended to me by one of my piano pupils, a gentle, sweet-natured 11 year old ballerina.<br /><br /> I found it an utter pleasure, despite the fact that I am the kind of mother who found Grimm's fairy tales to be much too grim, and censored them for violence, when I read to my young children.<br /><br /> Dahl's fantasy is presented in matter-of-fact, ordinary language as if it were a newspaper story, and that is part of the enchantment. The narrator takes you in and bears you along in a story that becomes ever more fancifully bizarre. When you reach the ending, which would seem bleak if not for the cotton-candy spun delight of the story, you take it in stride.<br /><br /> &quot;The Witches&quot; is not for the literal-minded child, but for children who can understand a story as an exercise in imagination, it is highly recommended.
B0000CABBW|4.0|&quot;Dedicated to those who have gone before.&quot; Wow. Absolutely gorgeous scenery in this movie. New Zealand? Goodness. Sign me up I want to go. Lush greens and beautiful ocean. The people? Diverse (with pretty cool accents). This one is heavy on tradition. The old ways mingled with some modern conveniences. One family's tragedy taken to an enlightening conclusion. It's an interesting film. Through most it, I just wanted to give that little girl (Keisha Castle-Hughes) a big hug (i.e., she's a good actress). Funny how the most stubborn and seemingly uncaring individuals somehow end up being the ones who care the most. It's just a shame that to realize it, an exceptional event must take place, which isn't so typical, but certainly entertaining. Expectations based on potential is one thing. But governing a life (and those to come) based on gender and family tradition alone is another matter altogether. Oppression sometimes inspires miracles. Such is the case here. A rather beautiful one at that. Time to break the barriers and allow a new tradition to evolve. I definitely recommend this movie. If nothing else, it's a poignant reminder of how differently people in other parts of the world live.

I believe that was the true goal of this disc.      I used to fault the Beatles for not creating a true greatest hits (the Red and Blue albums are de-facto) but now I know why they didn't. Their albums are truly meant to be experience in sequence.       The thirteen original albums, two single-collections (Past Master's), and the three Anthology can follow on.      All in all, a great sample, but as said, not definative.      ****

B000067CPX|5.0|mastering the art of funk rock and paving the way for rap rock, the red hot chili peppers have successfully done what many bands cannot do: change their sound without alienating their fanbase. the chili peppers do exactly that on their 2002 release 'by the way', a melodramatic joy ride through wavy guitar work from john fruiscante, funky bass lines from flea and sweet and calm vocals from anthony kiedis. the album isn't like their 1999 release 'californication' so if you were expecting a duplicate of it then you're mistaken. throughout the album's 16 tracks, the sound changes from time to time, from the funky bass lines and pounding toms of the opening title track to the soft, beach boys-like anthem of 'tear'. one of the most stand-out tracks on the album is 'can't stop', an homage to their old funk rock days and proving to everybody that they've still got it. even simple commands like in the track 'throw away your television' has everybody hooked because of its jungle beat and bass lines. <br /> <br />this album deserves a definate listen from everybody, even if you don't like their new sound. the chili peppers have grown out of their drug-induced lifestyle and have learned from their mistakes. 'californication' was a bittersweet symphony from their past, and now 'by the way' is a celebration of their transition from silly funk rock to classic potential for a spot in the rock n roll hall of fame.

B00000D9TQ|4.0|Phil Collins has had SO many hit singles, that a greatest-hits package was inevitable. &quot;Hits&quot; collects a big 74 minutes-worth of Phil's best-known tunes, such as &quot;In The Air Tonight,&quot; &quot;You Can't Hurry Love,&quot; &quot;One More Night,&quot; &quot;Sussudio,&quot; &quot;Take Me Home,&quot; and &quot;Another Day In Paradise,&quot; to name but a few. The album also collects for the first time Phil's hits from movie soundtracks, such as the smash &quot;Against All Odds,&quot; his hit duet with Marilyn Martin, &quot;Separate Lives&quot; (where is Marilyn Martin these days, by the way?), &quot;Groovy Kind Of Love,&quot; and &quot;Two Hearts.&quot; There's also his hit duet with Philip Bailey, &quot;Easy Lover,&quot; AND one brand-new track, a cover of Cyndi Lauper's hit song, &quot;True Colors&quot; (which I happen to like better than Cyndi's original version!). And yet, &quot;Hits&quot; is an incomplete Phil retrospective, as there are a handful of surprising ommissions---&quot;I Missed Again&quot; (which was Phil's very first hit single), &quot;I Don't Care Anymore,&quot; &quot;Don't Lose My Number,&quot; &quot;Do You Remember,&quot; and &quot;Everyday.&quot; Obviously, these were left off the album due to lack of space, but still, it's a disappointment. Hopefully, Phil will one day get a proper *2-disc* set of his biggest tunes, which would solve the problem right there. I can see it now---&quot;The Essential Phil Collins&quot;! They could also toss in a few extra goodies, like &quot;Thru These Walls,&quot; &quot;Oughta Know By Now,&quot; &quot;You'll Be In My Heart,&quot; &quot;Can't Stop Loving You,&quot; and &quot;Testify.&quot; I'm sure it'll happen eventually. For now, though, &quot;Hits,&quot; while incomplete, is still a very cool Phil Collins collection.
B000003TAR|5.0|As far as &quot;grunge&quot; goes this album fits into the moniker snugly. The sound is raw, heavy, and sludgey all the things the term denotes. Grunge consisted of four bands which broke the music barriers of the day and age. They were Nirvana, Pearl Jam, Soundgarden, and Alice In Chains.  <br />  <br /> Each had their own commercial radio hit that drove them into excess of 10 million sales EACH. Pearl Jam had Ten, Soundgarden had Superunknown, Alice in Chains had Dirt, and of course Nirvana had Nevermind. But beneath all the glamour and glitz of grunge each artist had their own musical masterpiece which went completely under-appreciated. Pearl Jam's No Code, Soundgarden's Badmotorfinger, Alice in Chains self-titled lp, and Nirvana's In Utero.  <br />  <br /> Far and away from the overly produced Nevermind In Utero stands as an artistic triumph for the band. The lyrical competence underwent a change as Kurt's song matured from the turbo-charged punk of Nevermind into complex and meaningful songs. &quot;She come's back as fire to burn all the liars, Leave a blanket of ash on the ground&quot; from Frances Farmer is the perfect example of deep and thought provoking words.  <br />  <br /> The instrumental work is also much tighter here with better musicianship from Grohl and Noveselic but from Cobain especially. Gone is the sloppiness from past works. Grohl's drumming is truly professional here with beats and pounds to match any of the past greats. Novoselic's bass is above competent and he really contributes to the band which seemed to be missing from earlier works. <br />  <br /> However,In Utero is by no means for first time listeners. It's sound hits you like a needle driven in through you're ear and pulled out and stabbed repeatedly. While Nevermind was a much friendlier album Kurt took In Utero into a new direction from the depression he was feeling and his intense abuse of herion. People just getting interested in Nirvana should start of with the seminal Nevermind or their self titled 'Greatest Hits' collection. For people looking for art as music this is it.  <br />  <br /> Tragically, following the path of Andy Wood the singer of Mother Love Bone who OD'ed on herion Kurt imploded killing himself in a herion induced hell in '94. Other greats such as Layne Stanley would fall and other bands would crumble but the early 90's will always be remembered as one of the best times in music history. Period.
B0002IQJUK|5.0|As many people have heard of Gavin from his song &quot;I Don't Want To Be&quot; on The WB's hit show, One Tree Hill, this remarkable marketing strategy has given the musician continuing curiosity with his music.  <br />  <br /> As a fan, I learned about Gavin from a magazine, and proceeded to purchase his cd because I thought he might be really good. And I'm glad I did that because it was the best investment I have ever made.  <br />  <br /> Gavin's debut disc, Chariot, is a remarkable set of piano-driven tunes with vocals that exemplify the passion that he holds for music. When he sings the lyrics to each song, you feel that he's really experiencing the emotions each song showcases. It doesn't seem like a song just put together for an album, but it sounds like each word he sings, is something he truly feels.  <br />  <br /> I think it is difficult for someone to pick the best songs on Chariot, because it is such an excellent debut, but given the fact that is a review, I should choose some that showcase Gavin the best. I think &quot;Chariot&quot; is one of the best songs because it just gives his music an overall impressive light to what he is singing about. Another song, &quot;Meaning&quot;, is very interesting. The beginning of the song is very catchy, and if you listen to the words, [no pun intended] the meaning shines brightly.  <br />  <br /> The fact that Gavin has decided to completely stripped away the full-band element of the original recording of 'Chariot', it gives him more credibility as an artist because he wants to showcase his true talent, vocally and musically. Each song shines on the record, especially &quot;Chariot&quot;, &quot;[Nice To Meet You] Anyway&quot;, and &quot;Belief.&quot; The stripped, personal songs feel as though you are at a live show of his. Though, the listener is given this advantage with this record, it doesn't take away the joy and excitement of going to see Gavin truly play a live show. <br />  <br /> I think this disc an excellent investment for curious fans to hear from him before going to a live show. And it is a definite necessity to his already dedicated fans.
B00000IQW5|5.0|This is one of my favorite movies. Simple, moving - it makes me laugh and it makes me cry. I tell people that it's a movie that slipped through without being noticed, and I'm not sure why.... Whenever I need to feel at home - I watch it.
B000286S8S|3.0|It's no secret that there's a deep animosity between Van Halen-particularly their leader,guitarist Edward(i.e Eddie) Van Halen-and their former frontman,David Lee Roth.His 1985 departure was acrimonious,and while his solo career paled in comparison with Van Halen's continued success with Sammy Hagar as their frontman,the group never escaped the shadow of DLR.No matter how many #1 albums,hit singles and sold-out shows they had,fans and critics alike preferred their gonzo days with Roth,and kept hounding the band for a reunion.Eddie held his ground for years,but once the band commercially stumbled with 1995's Balance,he reconsidered,courting Dave for an ill-fated semireunion on the 1996 Best Of album-a move that not only resulted in 2 enjoyable if underwhelming songs,but also the alienation of Sammy,who either quit over the matter or was fired(depending on who you ask).After that debacle,Van Halen chose former Extreme singer Gary Cherone for 1998's Van Halen III,but instead of being a new beginning,the album torpedoed both the band's career and their record contract.Years passed with no activity,and the silence whetted the appetite for a reunion-which for many meant one with Dave,not Sammy,but bad blood can run deep,so when Edward pulled the rest of the group together for a comeback tour in 2004,he chose Hagar as the frontman.To promote the tour,they put together a new hits compilation,the doubled-disc,36-track Best Of Both Worlds.On the surface,it seemed like the the ideal solution to the problems that plagued the first,half-baked Best Of,which at one disc couldn't possibly have fit both the best of both the Dave or Sammy years,but Best of Both Worlds turns out to be yet another botched collection,and one of the reasons it doesn't work as well as it should is that animosity toward David Lee Roth.                                                            Since the band's sound and massive popularity were built on the records they made with Roth,there was no way for Van Halen to ignore his contribution,but they do their damnest to diminish it here.There are no pictures of Diamond Dave to be found(unless small reproductions of the covers of VH1 and Women An Children First count) and David Wild's essay only mentions him twice-once when he joins,once when he exits-while conspicuosly lavishing praise on Sammy.As petty as this swipe is,it's understandable and could even be forgivable if the 2 discs were well assembled,but it's sabotaged by the absurd,jarring Dave-song-followed-by-a-Sammy-song sequencing,causing a whiplash change of tone,mood,and attitude(i.e Runnin With The Devil with When It's Love)with every song,which are otherwise well-chosen,containing most of the biggest and best from both eras(the only exceptions being the boneheaded move to end the collection with 3 live cuts with DLR songs all sungs by Sammy and the 3 lame new songs with Sammy).This attempt to elevate Sammy Hagar above David Lee Roth in the canon is a bit like trying to say Ronnie James Dio was more important to Black Sabbath than Ozzy Osbourne-a piece of flat-out hyperbole that does a disservice to what the singer really achieved.David Lee Roth was larger than life,a gonzo performance artist touched with genius who made Van Halen seem bigger,siller,grander than any other heavy-metal or AOR oufit at the time;with him in front,they were giants,they were the Golden Gods Of Rock'N Roll.Sammy Hagar was his total opposite,an ordinary-average guy who sang about girls and tequila,someboby who brought Van Halen back down to earth.Since part of the fun of rock stars is to have them larger than life,a manifestation of the audience's dreams,fans naturally gravitate towards the DLR years,but there are merits to both approaches and both resulted in good to great music.But that's hard to apperciate on Best Of Both Worlds,when the Dave and Sammy tunes are mixed up with no regard for chronological,musical,or emotional cohesiveness.The raw materials are here for a great VanHalen compilation-it's just up to users to take these 36 songs and sequence them at home to make this the the compilation it should have been.

B00012FXB8|3.0|I would give this film 4 stars only because the performance of Sigourney Weaver as Ripley, now a cinematic icon, raises it above the pack. Otherwise, it is often too repetitive--'Aliens' without the flamethrowers--though the cast makes a valiant effort to separate this film from its predecessors and nearly succeeds. Perhaps it deserves  four stars anyway based on its status as a cinematic icon. Some of the special effects early in the film are pretty awesome. The idea of having a woman crash land on a male prison colony is a promising one, but two of this film's leaders, the prison doctor and the prison warden, are killed off early leaving a significant leadership gap which is put in the questionable hands of Charles Dutton and his fellow prisoners. The early part of the film is suspenseful, as Ripley requests an autopsy of Newt from Aliens and has a brief affair with the medical director. After the prison doctor and warden die,and Sigourney comes face-to-face with the alien, the film suffers from plodding direction though it is full of chase scenes and there are some nice moments, such as when the alien, covered with molten lead, rises up and is smashed to smithereens by the sprinkler system, presumably because of the temperature difference. Charles Dutton also makes a solemn pact with Sigourney to kill her (because she is carrying a queen alien) after killing the alien, an idea that works pretty well. The idea that the scientists have no interest in the prisoners or in Sigourney as people but want to use the alien for questionable research goals is also a good one. Like the previous film, this film is bathed in red as a primary color and I for one don't see much difference between the two facilities.   The film I will compare it to is Kevin Bacon's 'The Hollow Man.' While \\"Alien 3\\" is pretty serious, \\"Hollow Man\\" has some comedic elements that were also present in the original \\"Invisible Man\\" which it resembles. 'The Hollow Man' starts out as apparently about scientific research, with Bacon playing an egotistical scientist in Washington, D.C. who is able by quantum physics to make living creatures disappear and reappear again. For this he receives government funding. They decide with all gravitas to try this technique on a human.Full of interesting special effects and computer graphics , the film soon degenerates into a horror/comedy film of somewhat low repute as Bacon himself disappears and uses this advantage to seduce unsuspecting women and to kill people. This transformation from mad scientist to evildoer is not totally out of keeping with the original \\"Invisible Man\\". There is quite a bit of blood and gore and also some pretty exciting action sequences including scenes in a freezer and elevator shaft and in the end, everybody has a good time, so this movie, despite its ridiculous nature, probably deserves 4 stars for the special effects, if nothing else.

If you sit and listen to the tracks on Siamese Dream you will not know what to expect next. It is impossible to name the best songs on this album because they are all masterpieces! The guitar work is exquisite, although in most songs it is very simple save the solos. This is gleaming proof that quality not quantity is the most desirable path. Enough said for the music. The most catching and intoxicating part of this album, and all Smashing Pumpkins songs for that matter, is the lyrical geneous! Billy Corgan, while being one of the most incredible guitarists of our time, is also one of the most overlooked poets of our time. Most will not take the time to read and desypher his verses of squalor, maudlin, and angst, but would be very pleased if they did. Corgan deals with many issues in his songs from religion (Hummer) to heartache (Soma). B000007U6V|4.0|Autobahn might have been the first album that gave Kraftwerk their breakthrough but they already released three albums prior, Kraftwerk 1, 2, and Ralf & Florian. It's little wonder why they're so obscure, those albums are so &quot;out there&quot;, that it's truly not recommended for those who like their more accessible later albums (but of course, those who like the more unusual Krautrock acts out there would probably like those albums). Autobahn, released near the end of 1974 was their first chart-topping album. Wolfgang Flr was the new member of the band, and they added Klaus Roeder (who only appeared on this album) on electric violin. The title track became a hit when edited for single release. This title track is much more accessible than most everything they done before, but this cut relies on repetition and droning sounds, often simulating the drive on an autobahn (complete with the sounds of cars and car horns). Flute and guitar are also present, along with the synthesizers. This was the first time vocals were used on the album, and this song was sung in German. But unfortunately the rest of the album gets ignored, which isn't fair. The second half of the album is all-instrumental, and a lot less accessible. This music harkens back to their pre-Autobahn albums, highly experimental music with lots of bizarre synthesizers, and one using electric violin. That last cut, &quot;Morgenspaziergang&quot; I can live without, going for more of Bavarian sound complete with dulcimers. It's basically a theme from &quot;Autobahn&quot; with recorders and dulcimers that don't quite work. Regardless, a great album to have in your collection.

B00005NTJK|5.0|Benefit was of course, the precursor to Aqualung, and points to the direction of that album. Most people tend to think Stand Up was Tull's best pre-Aqualung album, but for me I think it's Benefit. It's a more mature offering, not to mention it has a darker tone. The blues of previous albums (like &quot;A New Day Yesterday&quot; and &quot;A Song For Jeffrey&quot;) had pretty much vanished. In the US, this album featured &quot;Teacher&quot;, a song that became an FM radio favorite. Over in the UK, it wasn't featured on the album (it was released as a single with &quot;Witches Promise&quot;), and instead featured &quot;Alive and Well and Living In&quot; (which luckily for us Americans we got to hear on the Living in the Past compilation album). This album featured the premiere of John Evan on organ and piano, but he wasn't quite a full-time member yet. Anderson's flute playing is only featured on five of the album's ten songs, but regardless the album is still full of great songs. &quot;With You To Help Me&quot; features some nice use of flute (that sounds like it was recorded backwards). You get to hear Evan's use of piano. Martin Barre rocks out in places. &quot;Nothing to Say&quot; shows how great a Tull song can be even when the flute isn't present. &quot;Alive and Well and Living In&quot; (not on the US release) is mainly a piano-dominated piece. The US version features in its place &quot;Inside&quot; (which the UK version uses this song in place of &quot;Teacher&quot; on side two). A nice catchy, almost singalong piece, with nice use of flute. &quot;With Michael Collins, Jeffery and Me&quot; is a song that most resembles one of the acoustic interludes found on their following album, Aqualung. I just love how this song alternates between mellow and acoustic to rocking. &quot;To Cry You a Song&quot; is basically Martin Barre's time to shine, as it's completely guitar dominated with only Anderson providing the vocals. &quot;Play in Time&quot; is a strange piece, with Anderson's flute and John Evan's piano (with the tape played in reverse). &quot;Sossity, You're a Woman&quot; is a completely acoustic piece. I felt this piece was a bit underrated, because I actually find it an excellent piece. This was Tull's last album with Glenn Cornick, as he would move on to a group called Wild Turkey (which featured Ritchie Blackmore's brother Jon Blackmore, future Rick Wakeman vocalist Garry Pickford-Hopkins, and members of the Welsh band Man, Jeff Jones and &quot;Tweke&quot; Lewis). Unfortunately Benefit don't get the attention their next two albums would get (Aqualung, Thick as a Brick), but I actually felt this to be better than Aqualung. Might not be as easy to get in to as Stand Up, but a great album still the same.
B00006FDCJ|5.0|An aged gunman, William Munny (Clint Eastwood), is offered a job by The Schofield Kid (Jaimz Woolvett). Munny is to assist this young gunslinger in killing a couple of men, with bounties on their heads, for beating a hooker. Munny reluctantly accepts the job, desperately in need of cash. He and The Schofield Kid are joined by Munny's old partner (Morgan Freemen) as they set out on their journey. The only thing that stands in there way is the sinister sheriff (Gene Hackman) of a small town <br /> <br />Unforgiven is a unique western in that where most westerns glorify violence and bloodshed, Unforgiven examines the psychological effects of violence, the finality of murder, and the fragility of life. One death, in particular, is drawn out and made quite unpleasant without being gratuitous. The film is meticulously paced, which allows the viewer to think and reflect on how easily violent acts can be committed and the impact they have on the perpetrator and those close to the victims. Munny is haunted by the ghosts of those he has killed. Having committed the act of murder, The Schofield Kid is horrified and disgusted with himself. Gunslinging isn't what it's cracked up to be. <br /> <br />David Webb Peoples's original screenplay allows the film's characters to develop and break free of their western clichs. Eastwood's character represents a deconstruction of his famed tough guy career. Eastwood sheds his \\"Dirty Harry\\" persona to play a man who has grown weary and regretful of the crimes and the murders he committed in his past. Jaimz Woolvett plays The Schofield Kid, a character who - on the surface - appears to be the formulaic cocky gunslinger; but is actually a richly developed character with many unseen truths. Gene Hackman, Morgan Freemen, and Richard Harris round out the superb cast.  <br /> <br />Unforgiven's impeccable period detail greatly adds to the film's realism. The lack of vibrancy in the film's color palette and the heavy use of shadows greatly contribute to the state of the dismal characters and the heaviness of the subject matter. <br /> <br />Unforgiven is very much unlike Sergio Leone's bold and operatic westerns, which are wonderful films in their own right. Superfluous gun fights are not to be found here. It is a gritty western steeped in reality.
